item.title: Mathematical Insights into Protein Architecture: Persistent Homology and Machine Learning Applied to the Flagellar Motor
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: persistent homology, bacterial flagellar motor, topological data analysis, machine learning, protein function prediction

Summary:

1. The study introduces a machine learning method that uses persistent homology, a tool from topological data analysis, to classify bacterial flagellar motors into two states: rotated and stalled.

2. Protein structural data are embedded into a topological framework by constructing filtered simplicial complexes from atomic coordinates, enabling extraction of multiscale topological features.

3. Key topological invariants, including persistence diagrams and barcodes, capture geometric and connectivity patterns that correlate closely with the functional state of the motors.

4. These topological features are vectorized and input into a machine learning pipeline comprising dimensionality reduction followed by supervised classification, allowing the model to handle complex structural variations.

5. Applied on a curated dataset of experimentally characterized flagellar motors from diverse bacterial species, this approach achieves high accuracy and robustness, emphasizing the value of topological data analysis beyond traditional geometric descriptors for protein function prediction.
arXiv:2504.16941v4 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: We present a machine learning approach that leverages persistent homology to classify bacterial flagellar motors into two functional states: rotated and stalled. By embedding protein structural data into a topological framework, we extract multiscale features from filtered simplicial complexes constructed over atomic coordinates. These topological invariants, specifically persistence diagrams and barcodes, capture critical geometric and connectivity patterns that correlate with motor function. The extracted features are vectorized and integrated into a machine learning pipeline that includes dimensionality reduction and supervised classification. Applied to a curated dataset of experimentally characterized flagellar motors from diverse bacterial species, our model demonstrates high classification accuracy and robustness to structural variation. This approach highlights the power of topological data analysis in revealing functionally relevant patterns beyond the reach of traditional geometric descriptors, offering a novel computational tool for protein function prediction.

item.title: GiBy: A Giant-Step Baby-Step Classifier For Anomaly Detection In Industrial Control Systems
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: anomaly detection, industrial control systems, linearization, explainability, water treatment testbed

Summary:

1. The paper emphasizes the importance of continuous monitoring of cyber-physical components in industrial control systems (ICS) to ensure safe automation and fail-safe plant operations.
2. Safety is ensured by managing actuator commands based on sensor readings, which serve as ground truth for decision-making.
3. Detecting anomalies such as attacks, faults, and uncertain states in ICS is critical for plant safety, personnel protection, and service reliability.
4. The authors propose an anomaly detection approach utilizing accurate linearization of nonlinear sensor-actuator relationships, since linear models are simpler and well-studied.
5. Their approach is demonstrated using a water treatment testbed, showing millisecond-level anomaly detection response.
6. The method excels in both detection speed and explainability, outperforming existing AI/ML models integrated with explainable AI (XAI) for similar purposes.
7. Explainability allows pinpointing specific sensors and actuator states involved in detected anomalies.
8. The algorithm achieved 97.72% accuracy by correctly classifying deviations within safe limits as non-anomalous, indicating that ultra-high-resolution but slower detectors are unnecessary when safety boundaries have tolerance.
9. Overall, the method offers a fast, accurate, and interpretable tool for ICS anomaly detection, enhancing operational safety and reliability.
arXiv:2504.20906v3 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: The continuous monitoring of the interactions between cyber-physical components of any industrial control system (ICS) is required to secure automation of the system controls, and to guarantee plant processes are fail-safe and remain in an acceptably safe state. Safety is achieved by managing actuation (where electric signals are used to trigger physical movement), dependent on corresponding sensor readings; used as ground truth in decision making. Timely detection of anomalies (attacks, faults and unascertained states) in ICSs is crucial for the safe running of a plant, the safety of its personnel, and for the safe provision of any services provided. We propose an anomaly detection method that involves accurate linearization of the non-linear forms arising from sensor-actuator(s) relationships, primarily because solving linear models is easier and well understood. We accomplish this by using a well-known water treatment testbed as a use case. Our experiments show millisecond time response to detect anomalies, all of which are explainable and traceable; this simultaneous coupling of detection speed and explainability has not been achieved by other state of the art Artificial Intelligence (AI)/ Machine Learning (ML) models with eXplainable AI (XAI) used for the same purpose. Our methods explainability enables us to pin-point the sensor(s) and the actuation state(s) for which the anomaly was detected. The proposed algorithm showed an accuracy of 97.72% by flagging deviations within safe operation limits as non-anomalous; indicative that slower detectors with highest detection resolution is unnecessary, for systems whose safety boundaries provide leeway within safety limits.

item.title: Prototype-Guided Non-Exemplar Continual Learning for Cross-subject EEG Decoding
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: EEG decoding, continual learning, prototype memory, knowledge distillation, cross-subject alignment

Summary: Due to large variability in EEG signals across individuals, continual learning models for EEG decoding face the challenge of catastrophic forgetting, where knowledge from previous subjects is lost as new subjects are introduced. Existing methods often rely on storing historical EEG data as replay buffers to mitigate forgetting, but this is impractical due to privacy issues and memory limits. This paper proposes a Prototype-guided Non-Exemplar Continual Learning (ProNECL) framework that preserves learned knowledge without retaining any raw EEG samples. ProNECL creates class-level prototypes that summarize discriminative features from each subject, effectively capturing essential information in a compressed form. The framework incrementally aligns features from new subjects with these global prototype memories by employing cross-subject feature alignment and knowledge distillation techniques. Experimental validation on two benchmark datasets, BCI Competition IV 2a and 2b, demonstrates that ProNECL successfully balances the retention of previous knowledge with adaptability to new subjects. The proposed method achieves superior performance in cross-subject continual EEG decoding tasks compared to traditional approaches, highlighting its potential for privacy-preserving and efficient EEG-based brain-computer interface applications.
arXiv:2511.20696v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Due to the significant variability in electroencephalogram (EEG) signals across individuals, knowledge acquired from previous subjects is often overwritten as new subjects are introduced in continual EEG decoding task. Current works mainly rely on storing the historical data of seen subjects as a replay buffer to prevent forgetting. However, privacy concerns or memory constraints make keeping such data impractical. Instead, we propose a Prototype-guided Non-Exemplar Continual Learning (ProNECL)framework that preserves prior knowledge without accessing any historical EEG samples. ProNECL constructs class-level prototypes to summarize discriminative representations from each subject and incrementally aligns new feature spaces with the global prototype memory through cross-subject feature alignment and knowledge distillation. Validated on the BCI Competition IV 2a and 2b datasets, our framework effectively balances knowledge retention and adaptability, achieving superior performance in cross-subject continual EEG decoding tasks.

item.title: On the Role of Hidden States of Modern Hopfield Network in Transformer
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Hopfield networks, self-attention, Transformers, modern Hopfield attention, rank collapse

Summary: This paper investigates the connection between modern Hopfield networks (MHNs) and the self-attention mechanism used in Transformers, going beyond the previously known adiabatic approximation. A new variable, the hidden state derived from the MHN, is introduced into the self-attention framework, resulting in a novel attention mechanism called modern Hopfield attention (MHA). MHA allows attention scores from the input layer of the Transformer to be inherited by the output layer, enhancing the quality and stability of attention weights. The study addresses critical challenges in deep Transformers, specifically rank collapse and token uniformity, both theoretically and empirically showing significant improvements using MHA hidden states. Importantly, the proposed modification improves model accuracy in Vision Transformer and GPT architectures without increasing the number of training parameters. This work highlights the beneficial role that ideas from Hopfield networks can play in advancing the Transformer architecture, offering a new perspective for designing more robust and effective attention mechanisms in deep learning models.
arXiv:2511.20698v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Associative memory models based on Hopfield networks and self-attention based on key-value mechanisms have been popular approaches in the study of memory mechanisms in deep learning. It has been pointed out that the state update rule of the modern Hopfield network (MHN) in the adiabatic approximation is in agreement with the self-attention layer of Transformer. In this paper, we go beyond this approximation and investigate the relationship between MHN and self-attention. Our results show that the correspondence between Hopfield networks and Transformers can be established in a more generalized form by adding a new variable, the hidden state derived from the MHN, to self-attention. This new attention mechanism, modern Hopfield attention (MHA), allows the inheritance of attention scores from the input layer of the Transformer to the output layer, which greatly improves the nature of attention weights. In particular, we show both theoretically and empirically that MHA hidden states significantly improve serious problem of deep Transformers known as rank collapse and token uniformity. We also confirm that MHA can systematically improve accuracy without adding training parameters to the Vision Transformer or GPT. Our results provide a new case in which Hopfield networks can be a useful perspective for improving the Transformer architecture.

item.title: Post-Pruning Accuracy Recovery via Data-Free Knowledge Distillation
item.content:encoded:
Model pruning, Data-Free Knowledge Distillation, DeepInversion, Batch Normalization, Privacy-preserving

Summary:

1. The paper addresses the challenge of model pruning in Deep Neural Networks (DNNs), focusing on the accuracy degradation often caused by global unstructured pruning. 2. It highlights the difficulty of fine-tuning pruned models in privacy-sensitive domains, such as healthcare and finance, where original training data cannot be accessed post-deployment due to legal regulations like GDPR and HIPAA. 3. To overcome this, the authors propose a novel Data-Free Knowledge Distillation framework that synthesizes "dream" images from the pretrained teacher model using DeepInversion by inverting Batch Normalization statistics, thus avoiding the need for real data. 4. These synthetic images act as a transfer set to distill knowledge from the original teacher model to the pruned student model, facilitating accurate model compression without data privacy compromises. 5. Experimental evaluations on CIFAR-10 using various architectures (ResNet, MobileNet, VGG) demonstrate that the proposed method effectively recovers the accuracy lost during pruning, achieving significant improvements without accessing any real training samples. This approach provides a practical solution to deploy compressed DNNs securely in privacy-sensitive applications.
arXiv:2511.20702v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Model pruning is a widely adopted technique to reduce the computational complexity and memory footprint of Deep Neural Networks (DNNs). However, global unstructured pruning often leads to significant degradation in accuracy, typically necessitating fine-tuning on the original training dataset to recover performance. In privacy-sensitive domains such as healthcare or finance, access to the original training data is often restricted post-deployment due to regulations (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA). This paper proposes a Data-Free Knowledge Distillation framework to bridge the gap between model compression and data privacy. We utilize DeepInversion to synthesize privacy-preserving ``dream'' images from the pre-trained teacher model by inverting Batch Normalization (BN) statistics. These synthetic images serve as a transfer set to distill knowledge from the original teacher to the pruned student network. Experimental results on CIFAR-10 across various architectures (ResNet, MobileNet, VGG) demonstrate that our method significantly recovers accuracy lost during pruning without accessing a single real data point.

item.title: Pretraining Transformer-Based Models on Diffusion-Generated Synthetic Graphs for Alzheimer's Disease Prediction
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Alzheimer's disease, diffusion model, graph transformer, synthetic data, transfer learning

Summary: Early and accurate detection of Alzheimer's disease (AD) is essential to enable timely intervention and improve patient outcomes. The development of robust machine learning models for AD diagnosis is hindered by challenges including limited labeled data, class imbalance, and heterogeneity across multiple clinical sites. To address these issues, the authors propose a Transformer-based diagnostic framework that integrates diffusion-based synthetic data generation with graph representation learning and transfer learning. They employ a class-conditional denoising diffusion probabilistic model (DDPM) trained on the NACC dataset to generate a large synthetic cohort that replicates multimodal clinical and neuroimaging feature distributions while balancing diagnostic classes. Modality-specific Graph Transformer encoders are pretrained on this synthetic data to learn class-discriminative and robust feature embeddings, which are then fixed during the training of a neural classifier on the original NACC data. The study measures alignment between synthetic and real data distributions using metrics such as Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD), Frechet distance, and energy distance and evaluates diagnostic performance by calibration and fixed-specificity sensitivity analyses. The results demonstrate that this approach outperforms standard baselines, including early and late fusion deep neural networks and the graph-based model MaGNet, showing improved AUC, accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity in subject-wise cross-validation. Overall, diffusion-based synthetic pretraining combined with Graph Transformers enhances generalization in low-sample, imbalanced clinical prediction tasks.
arXiv:2511.20704v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Early and accurate detection of Alzheimer's disease (AD) is crucial for enabling timely intervention and improving outcomes. However, developing reliable machine learning (ML) models for AD diagnosis is challenging due to limited labeled data, multi-site heterogeneity, and class imbalance. We propose a Transformer-based diagnostic framework that combines diffusion-based synthetic data generation with graph representation learning and transfer learning. A class-conditional denoising diffusion probabilistic model (DDPM) is trained on the real-world NACC dataset to generate a large synthetic cohort that mirrors multimodal clinical and neuroimaging feature distributions while balancing diagnostic classes. Modality-specific Graph Transformer encoders are first pretrained on this synthetic data to learn robust, class-discriminative representations and are then frozen while a neural classifier is trained on embeddings from the original NACC data. We quantify distributional alignment between real and synthetic cohorts using metrics such as Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD), Frechet distance, and energy distance, and complement discrimination metrics with calibration and fixed-specificity sensitivity analyses. Empirically, our framework outperforms standard baselines, including early and late fusion deep neural networks and the multimodal graph-based model MaGNet, yielding higher AUC, accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity under subject-wise cross-validation on NACC. These results show that diffusion-based synthetic pretraining with Graph Transformers can improve generalization in low-sample, imbalanced clinical prediction settings.

item.title: Solving Diffusion Inverse Problems with Restart Posterior Sampling
item.content:encoded:
Inverse problems, diffusion models, posterior sampling, restart strategy, non-linear measurement models

Summary: Inverse problems involve estimating an unknown signal or state from incomplete or noisy observations, a challenge prevalent in science and engineering. Recent methods use diffusion models as implicit priors due to their capability to model complex data distributions, but they often depend on approximations of the posterior, require costly gradient backpropagation through the score network, or are limited to linear measurement settings. This paper introduces Restart for Posterior Sampling (RePS), a novel and general framework that addresses these limitations by enabling efficient sampling in both linear and non-linear inverse problems using pretrained diffusion models. RePS leverages conditioned ordinary differential equations (ODEs) compatible with any differentiable measurement model and incorporates a simplified restart mechanism that mitigates accumulated errors in iterative sampling, improving sample quality. Crucially, RePS avoids backpropagation through the score network, significantly reducing computational expenses. Experimental results demonstrate that RePS achieves faster convergence rates and better reconstruction fidelity compared to existing diffusion-based baselines across diverse inverse problem scenarios. This makes it a versatile, efficient, and high-performance approach for posterior inference with diffusion models, expanding their applicability beyond linear measurement models.
arXiv:2511.20705v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Inverse problems are fundamental to science and engineering, where the goal is to infer an underlying signal or state from incomplete or noisy measurements. Recent approaches employ diffusion models as powerful implicit priors for such problems, owing to their ability to capture complex data distributions. However, existing diffusion-based methods for inverse problems often rely on strong approximations of the posterior distribution, require computationally expensive gradient backpropagation through the score network, or are restricted to linear measurement models. In this work, we propose Restart for Posterior Sampling (RePS), a general and efficient framework for solving both linear and non-linear inverse problems using pre-trained diffusion models. RePS builds on the idea of restart-based sampling, previously shown to improve sample quality in unconditional diffusion, and extends it to posterior inference. Our method employs a conditioned ODE applicable to any differentiable measurement model and introduces a simplified restart strategy that contracts accumulated approximation errors during sampling. Unlike some of the prior approaches, RePS avoids backpropagation through the score network, substantially reducing computational cost. We demonstrate that RePS achieves faster convergence and superior reconstruction quality compared to existing diffusion-based baselines across a range of inverse problems, including both linear and non-linear settings.

item.title: Active Slice Discovery in Large Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Large Language Models, error slices, active slice discovery, toxicity classification, active learning

Summary:

1. Large Language Models (LLMs) often have systematic errors concentrated in specific data subsets called error slices, such as difficulties in correctly identifying toxic comments related to certain demographics.
2. Identifying these error slices is essential for understanding model weaknesses and improving performance but presents significant challenges due to the need for extensive manual annotation.
3. The paper introduces and formalizes the concept of Active Slice Discovery, an approach that actively groups model errors likely belonging to the same slice while efficiently using limited annotator input to verify shared error patterns.
4. The study applies this method empirically to the task of discovering known human-defined slices within toxicity classification datasets.
5. Experimental results indicate that uncertainty-based active learning algorithms are particularly effective, achieving good accuracy with only 2-10% of the available slice membership information, and significantly outperform several baseline methods under various feature representations and active learning strategies.
arXiv:2511.20713v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) often exhibit systematic errors on specific subsets of data, known as error slices. For instance, a slice can correspond to a certain demographic, where a model does poorly in identifying toxic comments regarding that demographic. Identifying error slices is crucial to understanding and improving models, but it is also challenging. An appealing approach to reduce the amount of manual annotation required is to actively group errors that are likely to belong to the same slice, while using limited access to an annotator to verify whether the chosen samples share the same pattern of model mistake. In this paper, we formalize this approach as Active Slice Discovery and explore it empirically on a problem of discovering human-defined slices in toxicity classification. We examine the efficacy of active slice discovery under different choices of feature representations and active learning algorithms. On several slices, we find that uncertainty-based active learning algorithms are most effective, achieving competitive accuracy using 2-10% of the available slice membership information, while significantly outperforming baselines.

item.title: ST-PPO: Stabilized Off-Policy Proximal Policy Optimization for Multi-Turn Agents Training
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: PPO, large language models, multi-turn dialogue, importance sampling, stabilization techniques

Summary: Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) is commonly used to train large language models (LLMs) for multi-turn dialogue and reasoning tasks at the token level but often suffers from instability and collapse. This instability primarily stems from two sources: token-level importance sampling misaligned with the natural turn-level granularity of these multi-turn environments, and inaccurate advantage estimation from off-policy samples where the critic is unreliable in evaluating certain state-action pairs, causing high-variance gradient updates. To tackle these issues, the paper proposes two complementary stabilization methods: turn-level importance sampling to better align optimization with the natural stage structure of multi-turn reasoning, and clipping-bias correction to normalize gradients by downweighting highly off-policy samples, reducing bias from clipped updates. These methods lead to three PPO variants: Turn-PPO (only turn-level sampling), S-PPO (clipping-bias correction with token-level PPO), and ST-PPO (both turn-level sampling and clipping-bias correction combined). Experiments conducted on multi-turn search tasks in general QA, multi-hop QA, and medical multiple-choice benchmarks demonstrate that ST-PPO and S-PPO consistently prevent training collapse, maintain lower clipping ratios during optimization, and outperform standard token-level PPO in task performance. Overall, integrating turn-level importance sampling with clipping-bias correction offers a practical and scalable means of stabilizing multi-turn LLM agent training.
arXiv:2511.20718v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: PPO has been widely adopted for training large language models (LLMs) at the token level in multi-turn dialogue and reasoning tasks. However, its performance is often unstable and prone to collapse. Through empirical analysis, we identify two main sources of instability in this setting: (1)~token-level importance sampling, which is misaligned with the natural granularity of multi-turn environments that have distinct turn-level stages, and (2) inaccurate advantage estimates from off-policy samples, where the critic has not learned to evaluate certain state-action pairs, resulting in high-variance gradients and unstable updates. To address these challenges, we introduce two complementary stabilization techniques: (1) turn-level importance sampling, which aligns optimization with the natural structure of multi-turn reasoning, and (2) clipping-bias correction, which normalizes gradients by downweighting unreliable, highly off-policy samples. Depending on how these components are combined, we obtain three variants: Turn-PPO (turn-level sampling only), S-PPO (clipping-bias correction applied to token-level PPO), and ST-PPO (turn-level sampling combined with clipping-bias correction). In our experiments, we primarily study ST-PPO and S-PPO, which together demonstrate how the two stabilization mechanisms address complementary sources of instability. Experiments on multi-turn search tasks across general QA, multi-hop QA, and medical multiple-choice QA benchmarks show that ST-PPO and S-PPO consistently prevent the performance collapses observed in large-model training, maintain lower clipping ratios throughout optimization, and achieve higher task performance than standard token-level PPO. These results demonstrate that combining turn-level importance sampling with clipping-bias correction provides a practical and scalable solution for stabilizing multi-turn LLM agent training.

item.title: Gradient Descent Algorithm Survey
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: optimization algorithms, deep learning, SGD, Adam, Lion

Summary: This article addresses the practical configuration requirements of optimization algorithms widely used in deep learning. It focuses on five major algorithms: SGD, Mini-batch SGD, Momentum, Adam, and Lion, analyzing their fundamental strengths and weaknesses. The study provides detailed practical recommendations for each algorithm, emphasizing how to select and tune parameters effectively to maximize performance. By offering a systematic comparison, the article aims to establish a standardized reference that supports both academic research and engineering applications. It highlights the importance of understanding algorithmic nuances to tackle optimization challenges across various model sizes and training scenarios. The research contributes to improved decision-making when choosing appropriate optimization strategies to enhance training efficiency and model accuracy.
arXiv:2511.20725v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Focusing on the practical configuration needs of optimization algorithms in deep learning, this article concentrates on five major algorithms: SGD, Mini-batch SGD, Momentum, Adam, and Lion. It systematically analyzes the core advantages, limitations, and key practical recommendations of each algorithm. The research aims to gain an in-depth understanding of these algorithms and provide a standardized reference for the reasonable selection, parameter tuning, and performance improvement of optimization algorithms in both academic research and engineering practice, helping to solve optimization challenges in different scales of models and various training scenarios.

item.title: Learning from Risk: LLM-Guided Generation of Safety-Critical Scenarios with Prior Knowledge
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: autonomous driving, scenario generation, conditional variational autoencoder, large language model, safety validation

Summary: This paper addresses key challenges in autonomous driving related to rare long-tail events and complex multi-agent interactions, which are underrepresented in real-world data but crucial for robust safety validation. The authors propose a high-fidelity scenario generation framework that combines a conditional variational autoencoder (CVAE) with a large language model (LLM). The CVAE leverages historical trajectories and map data from naturalistic datasets to learn latent traffic structures, enabling the creation of physically consistent base scenarios. The LLM enhances this by acting as an adversarial reasoning engine, transforming unstructured scene descriptions into domain-specific loss functions to guide scenario generation dynamically across various risk levels. This approach integrates knowledge-driven optimization to carefully balance scenario realism and controllability, ensuring plausibility while emphasizing risk sensitivity. Extensive evaluations in CARLA and SMARTS simulation environments reveal that the framework significantly increases coverage of high-risk and rare events, aligns simulated traffic distributions more closely with real-world data, and exposes autonomous driving systems to far more challenging multi-agent interactions compared to existing rule-based or purely data-driven methods. The results demonstrate a novel and effective pathway for safety validation, enabling principled stress-testing of autonomous systems under rare yet critical scenarios.
arXiv:2511.20726v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Autonomous driving faces critical challenges in rare long-tail events and complex multi-agent interactions, which are scarce in real-world data yet essential for robust safety validation. This paper presents a high-fidelity scenario generation framework that integrates a conditional variational autoencoder (CVAE) with a large language model (LLM). The CVAE encodes historical trajectories and map information from large-scale naturalistic datasets to learn latent traffic structures, enabling the generation of physically consistent base scenarios. Building on this, the LLM acts as an adversarial reasoning engine, parsing unstructured scene descriptions into domain-specific loss functions and dynamically guiding scenario generation across varying risk levels. This knowledge-driven optimization balances realism with controllability, ensuring that generated scenarios remain both plausible and risk-sensitive. Extensive experiments in CARLA and SMARTS demonstrate that our framework substantially increases the coverage of high-risk and long-tail events, improves consistency between simulated and real-world traffic distributions, and exposes autonomous driving systems to interactions that are significantly more challenging than those produced by existing rule- or data-driven methods. These results establish a new pathway for safety validation, enabling principled stress-testing of autonomous systems under rare but consequential events.

item.title: Spatio-Temporal Trajectory Foundation Model - Recent Advances and Future Directions
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Foundation models, spatio-temporal foundation models, trajectory foundation models, adaptability, knowledge discovery

Summary:

This article focuses on the emerging field of trajectory foundation models (TFMs), a specialized subset of spatio-temporal foundation models (STFMs) inspired by the success of large language models and foundation models in general. First, it outlines the significance of foundation models in enabling diverse data analytics and knowledge discovery across various scientific disciplines. Second, it acknowledges the recent trend toward developing STFMs to enhance adaptability and generalization for spatio-temporal tasks. Third, it identifies a notable gap in the literature—specifically a lack of systematic study regarding TFMs despite their importance. Fourth, the tutorial presented aims to fill this gap by providing a comprehensive overview of recent advances, including a taxonomy of existing TFM methodologies accompanied by a critical assessment of their respective strengths and limitations. Lastly, the article highlights several unresolved challenges and proposes promising future research directions to foster the development of robust, responsible, and transferable TFMs that contribute toward the broader goal of spatio-temporal general intelligence.
arXiv:2511.20729v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Foundation models (FMs) have emerged as a powerful paradigm, enabling a diverse range of data analytics and knowledge discovery tasks across scientific fields. Inspired by the success of FMs, particularly large language models, researchers have recently begun to explore spatio-temporal foundation models (STFMs) to improve adaptability and generalization across a wide spectrum of spatio-temporal (ST) tasks. Despite rapid progress, a systematic investigation of trajectory foundation models (TFMs), a crucial subclass of STFMs, is largely lacking. This tutorial addresses this gap by offering a comprehensive overview of recent advances in TFMs, including a taxonomy of existing methodologies and a critical analysis of their strengths and limitations. In addition, the tutorial highlights open challenges and outlines promising research directions to advance spatio-temporal general intelligence through the development of robust, responsible, and transferable TFMs.

item.title: CHiQPM: Calibrated Hierarchical Interpretable Image Classification
item.content:encoded:
Interpretability, Hierarchical explanations, Conformal prediction, Human-AI complementarity, Calibrated prediction

Summary: This paper introduces the Calibrated Hierarchical QPM (CHiQPM), a novel model designed to provide both global and local interpretability crucial for trustworthy AI, especially in safety-critical applications. CHiQPM enhances global interpretability through contrastive explanations that address the majority of classes, making the interpretive process more comprehensive. Additionally, it offers hierarchical explanations that mirror human reasoning processes, allowing users to explore explanations at multiple levels of detail. This hierarchical structure enables built-in conformal prediction (CP), producing calibrated set predictions that are interpretable and coherent. The model maintains state-of-the-art point prediction accuracy, achieving 99% of the accuracy of comparable non-interpretable models, thus demonstrating that interpretability does not come at the cost of performance. Moreover, CHiQPM’s calibrated set predictions are computationally efficient and competitive with existing CP methods, while uniquely providing interpretable explanations alongside these predictions. Overall, CHiQPM paves the way for enhanced human-AI collaboration by combining superior accuracy, interpretability, and calibrated decision making in a unified framework.
arXiv:2511.20779v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Globally interpretable models are a promising approach for trustworthy AI in safety-critical domains. Alongside global explanations, detailed local explanations are a crucial complement to effectively support human experts during inference. This work proposes the Calibrated Hierarchical QPM (CHiQPM) which offers uniquely comprehensive global and local interpretability, paving the way for human-AI complementarity. CHiQPM achieves superior global interpretability by contrastively explaining the majority of classes and offers novel hierarchical explanations that are more similar to how humans reason and can be traversed to offer a built-in interpretable Conformal prediction (CP) method. Our comprehensive evaluation shows that CHiQPM achieves state-of-the-art accuracy as a point predictor, maintaining 99% accuracy of non-interpretable models. This demonstrates a substantial improvement, where interpretability is incorporated without sacrificing overall accuracy. Furthermore, its calibrated set prediction is competitively efficient to other CP methods, while providing interpretable predictions of coherent sets along its hierarchical explanation.

item.title: Physics Steering: Causal Control of Cross-Domain Concepts in a Physics Foundation Model
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: mechanistic interpretability, large language models, foundation models, physics simulations, concept directions

Summary:

1. The paper explores whether the development of internal, human-understandable abstract representations is unique to models trained on structured data like language and images, or if it also appears in scientific foundation models focused on physics.

2. The authors analyze a large physics-focused foundation model by extracting activation vectors during forward passes over simulation datasets representing different physical regimes.

3. They compute "delta" representations by subtracting activations between two different regimes, treating these as concept directions encoding specific physical features within the model's activation space.

4. By injecting these concept directions into the model during inference, the researchers demonstrate the ability to steer the model’s predictions causally, effectively inducing or removing particular physical features in simulations.

5. The findings suggest that scientific foundation models develop generalized representations of physical principles beyond superficial correlations, offering new possibilities for understanding, controlling such models, and advancing AI-enabled scientific discovery.
arXiv:2511.20798v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent advances in mechanistic interpretability have revealed that large language models (LLMs) develop internal representations corresponding not only to concrete entities but also distinct, human-understandable abstract concepts and behaviour. Moreover, these hidden features can be directly manipulated to steer model behaviour. However, it remains an open question whether this phenomenon is unique to models trained on inherently structured data (ie. language, images) or if it is a general property of foundation models. In this work, we investigate the internal representations of a large physics-focused foundation model. Inspired by recent work identifying single directions in activation space for complex behaviours in LLMs, we extract activation vectors from the model during forward passes over simulation datasets for different physical regimes. We then compute "delta" representations between the two regimes. These delta tensors act as concept directions in activation space, encoding specific physical features. By injecting these concept directions back into the model during inference, we can steer its predictions, demonstrating causal control over physical behaviours, such as inducing or removing some particular physical feature from a simulation. These results suggest that scientific foundation models learn generalised representations of physical principles. They do not merely rely on superficial correlations and patterns in the simulations. Our findings open new avenues for understanding and controlling scientific foundation models and has implications for AI-enabled scientific discovery.

item.title: Conformal Safety Monitoring for Flight Testing: A Case Study in Data-Driven Safety Learning
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: runtime safety monitoring, flight testing, stochastic trajectory simulation, nearest neighbor classification, conformal prediction

Summary: This paper introduces a data-driven framework for runtime safety monitoring tailored for flight testing scenarios, where aircraft operate with uncertain parameters. The core challenge addressed is the unexpected emergence of safety violations due to parameter uncertainties during pilot maneuvers, necessitating reliable, early-warning criteria for pilots to abort risky maneuvers before violations occur. The proposed solution leverages offline stochastic trajectory simulations to build a calibrated statistical model that assesses short-term safety risk. The approach is demonstrated through a flight testing example, highlighting complexities due to safety risks, uncertainties, and human interaction. The methodology incorporates three key components: (1) a model that predicts the aircraft's future state based on recent observations, (2) a nearest neighbor classifier that evaluates the predicted state's safety, and (3) calibration of the classifier’s confidence using conformal prediction to provide reliable probabilistic guarantees. Experimental evaluation on a flight dynamics model with uncertain parameters proves the method’s effectiveness in accurately identifying unsafe conditions and surpassing baseline methods in risk classification. Furthermore, the approach aligns with theoretical safety guarantees, emphasizing its potential utility beyond flight testing to other dynamic systems requiring proactive safety monitoring.
arXiv:2511.20811v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We develop a data-driven approach for runtime safety monitoring in flight testing, where pilots perform maneuvers on aircraft with uncertain parameters. Because safety violations can arise unexpectedly as a result of these uncertainties, pilots need clear, preemptive criteria to abort the maneuver in advance of safety violation. To solve this problem, we use offline stochastic trajectory simulation to learn a calibrated statistical model of the short-term safety risk facing pilots. We use flight testing as a motivating example for data-driven learning/monitoring of safety due to its inherent safety risk, uncertainty, and human-interaction. However, our approach consists of three broadly-applicable components: a model to predict future state from recent observations, a nearest neighbor model to classify the safety of the predicted state, and classifier calibration via conformal prediction. We evaluate our method on a flight dynamics model with uncertain parameters, demonstrating its ability to reliably identify unsafe scenarios, match theoretical guarantees, and outperform baseline approaches in preemptive classification of risk.

item.title: Effects of Initialization Biases on Deep Neural Network Training Dynamics
item.content:encoded:
Initial Guessing Bias, neural networks, loss functions, training dynamics, robust learning

Summary:

This paper investigates a phenomenon termed Initial Guessing Bias (IGB) in large neural networks just after random initialization. IGB leads models to favor a small subset of classes with high predicted probabilities, while assigning near-zero probability to others. This bias notably influences early training dynamics, a critical phase when the model is adapting to the coarse data structure. The authors emphasize that the choice of loss function has a significant impact on how these early dynamics unfold. Specifically, two recent loss functions, Blurry loss and Piecewise-zero loss, which were initially designed to improve robustness against label errors, can fail to effectively guide training direction in the presence of Initial Guessing Bias. Experimental results demonstrate that loss functions differ dramatically in their ability to manage early training behavior under IGB. Overall, the study highlights the importance of carefully considering the interaction between Initial Guessing Bias and training components, especially loss functions, to ensure stable and effective early neural network training. This understanding could inform better design of training protocols and loss functions that mitigate the adverse impact of Initial Guessing Bias on model performance.
arXiv:2511.20826v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Untrained large neural networks, just after random initialization, tend to favour a small subset of classes, assigning high predicted probabilities to these few classes and approximately zero probability to all others. This bias, termed Initial Guessing Bias, affects the early training dynamics, when the model is fitting to the coarse structure of the data. The choice of loss function against which to train the model has a large impact on how these early dynamics play out. Two recent loss functions, Blurry and Piecewise-zero loss, were designed for robustness to label errors but can become unable to steer the direction of training when exposed to this initial bias. Results indicate that the choice of loss function has a dramatic effect on the early phase training of networks, and highlights the need for careful consideration of how Initial Guessing Bias may interact with various components of the training scheme.

item.title: Autoregressive Surrogate Modeling of the Solar Wind with Spherical Fourier Neural Operator
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: solar wind, machine learning, Spherical Fourier Neural Operator, space weather, surrogate modeling

Summary: 1. The solar wind is a continuous flow of charged particles from the Sun's corona that affects the heliosphere and space systems near Earth, making accurate modeling critical for space weather forecasting. 2. Traditional three-dimensional magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) models, while accurate, are computationally expensive and thus not well-suited for rapid exploration of uncertainties in boundary conditions. 3. This study introduces the first autoregressive machine learning proxy model for predicting steady-state solar wind radial velocity using the Spherical Fourier Neural Operator (SFNO). 4. The proposed method predicts the solar wind velocity over a limited radial range and iteratively propagates the solution outward, which enhances accuracy in regions farther from the Sun compared to a one-step prediction approach. 5. Benchmarking against the numerical Heliospheric Upwind eXtrapolation (HUX) surrogate shows that SFNO offers superior or comparable performance while being more flexible, trainable, and purely data-driven. 6. This work establishes a new methodology for high-fidelity solar wind modeling, enabling faster and more adaptable predictions essential for space weather applications. 7. The authors have made the source code and additional visualization results publicly available at their GitHub repository, facilitating further research and development in this area.
arXiv:2511.20830v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The solar wind, a continuous outflow of charged particles from the Sun's corona, shapes the heliosphere and impacts space systems near Earth. Accurate prediction of features such as high-speed streams and coronal mass ejections is critical for space weather forecasting, but traditional three-dimensional magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) models are computationally expensive, limiting rapid exploration of boundary condition uncertainties. We introduce the first autoregressive machine learning surrogate for steady-state solar wind radial velocity using the Spherical Fourier Neural Operator (SFNO). By predicting a limited radial range and iteratively propagating the solution outward, the model improves accuracy in distant regions compared to a single-step approach. Compared with the numerical HUX surrogate, SFNO demonstrates superior or comparable performance while providing a flexible, trainable, and data-driven alternative, establishing a novel methodology for high-fidelity solar wind modeling. The source code and additional visual results are available at https://github.com/rezmansouri/solarwind-sfno-velocity-autoregressive.

item.title: Primal: A Unified Deterministic Framework for Quasi-Orthogonal Hashing and Manifold Learning
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: deterministic feature mapping, prime square roots, StaticPrime, DynamicPrime, kernel map

Summary: This paper introduces Primal, a deterministic feature mapping framework leveraging number-theoretic properties of prime square roots to produce robust and tunable vector representations. Unlike stochastic approaches like Random Fourier Features, Primal exploits the Besicovitch property to generate irrational frequency modulations, ensuring infinite non-repeating phase trajectories. The authors propose two algorithmic variants: (1) StaticPrime, which generates temporal position encodings approaching the Welch bound for quasi-orthogonality, enhancing orthogonal sequence design, and (2) DynamicPrime, a tunable projection layer adapting feature mappings based on input, controlled by a scaling parameter σ. Notably, DynamicPrime unifies two mathematical utility classes: at low-frequency settings, it acts as an isometric kernel map that linearizes complex, non-convex geometries (such as spirals), facilitating tasks like signal reconstruction and compressive sensing; at high-frequency settings, it induces chaotic phase wrapping, functioning as a maximum-entropy one-way hash beneficial for Hyperdimensional Computing and privacy-preserving Split Learning. Empirical results demonstrate that Primal outperforms normalized Gaussian random projections in orthogonality preservation and distribution tightness, making it both computationally efficient and mathematically rigorous. The framework’s code implementation is publicly accessible on GitHub for reproduction and further research.
arXiv:2511.20839v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We present Primal, a deterministic feature mapping framework that harnesses the number-theoretic independence of prime square roots to construct robust, tunable vector representations. Diverging from standard stochastic projections (e.g., Random Fourier Features), our method exploits the Besicovitch property to create irrational frequency modulations that guarantee infinite non-repeating phase trajectories. We formalize two distinct algorithmic variants: (1) StaticPrime, a sequence generation method that produces temporal position encodings empirically approaching the theoretical Welch bound for quasi-orthogonality; and (2) DynamicPrime, a tunable projection layer for input-dependent feature mapping. A central novelty of the dynamic framework is its ability to unify two disparate mathematical utility classes through a single scaling parameter {\sigma}. In the low-frequency regime, the method acts as an isometric kernel map, effectively linearizing non-convex geometries (e.g., spirals) to enable high-fidelity signal reconstruction and compressive sensing. Conversely, the high-frequency regime induces chaotic phase wrapping, transforming the projection into a maximum-entropy one-way hash suitable for Hyperdimensional Computing and privacy-preserving Split Learning. Empirical evaluations demonstrate that our framework yields superior orthogonality retention and distribution tightness compared to normalized Gaussian baselines, establishing it as a computationally efficient, mathematically rigorous alternative to random matrix projections. The code is available at https://github.com/VladimerKhasia/primal

item.title: Pre-train to Gain: Robust Learning Without Clean Labels
item.content:encoded:
Noisy labels, self-supervised learning, feature extractor, CIFAR-10, label-error detection

Summary:

This paper addresses the challenge of training deep neural networks in the presence of noisy labels, which typically causes poor model generalization due to overfitting on incorrect labels. The authors propose a robust training pipeline that eliminates the need for a clean subset of labeled data. The method involves pre-training a feature extractor backbone using self-supervised learning (SSL) techniques such as SimCLR and Barlow Twins, which do not require any labels. After this unlabeled pre-training, the model undergoes supervised training on the noisy labeled dataset. Experiments conducted on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets under both synthetic and real-world noise scenarios demonstrate consistent improvements in classification accuracy across all noise levels. Additionally, the SSL pre-training enhances downstream label-error detection capabilities, achieving higher F1 scores and balanced accuracy. The benefits of the approach become more pronounced as the noise rate increases, indicating its superior noise robustness. Remarkably, the proposed method matches the performance of models pre-trained on large curated datasets like ImageNet when noise levels are low, and significantly outperforms them under high noise conditions. This shows its promise as a practical solution for noisy label scenarios without relying on clean data subsets.
arXiv:2511.20844v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Training deep networks with noisy labels leads to poor generalization and degraded accuracy due to overfitting to label noise. Existing approaches for learning with noisy labels often rely on the availability of a clean subset of data. By pre-training a feature extractor backbone without labels using self-supervised learning (SSL), followed by standard supervised training on the noisy dataset, we can train a more noise robust model without requiring a subset with clean labels. We evaluate the use of SimCLR and Barlow~Twins as SSL methods on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 under synthetic and real world noise. Across all noise rates, self-supervised pre-training consistently improves classification accuracy and enhances downstream label-error detection (F1 and Balanced Accuracy). The performance gap widens as the noise rate increases, demonstrating improved robustness. Notably, our approach achieves comparable results to ImageNet pre-trained models at low noise levels, while substantially outperforming them under high noise conditions.

item.title: Selecting Belief-State Approximations in Simulators with Latent States
item.content:encoded:
keywords: state resetting, simulators, belief state, conditional distribution selection, sampling algorithms

Summary: State resetting in simulators is a crucial feature that enables sample-based planning and calibration using real data by resetting to previously encountered states. When simulators contain latent variables, resetting requires sampling from the posterior distribution of the latent state given observable history, known as the belief state, which is often difficult to perform exactly. The paper reduces this challenge to a general conditional distribution-selection problem and proposes a new algorithm with theoretical analysis under sampling-only access. Two main formulations for belief-state selection are presented: latent state-based selection, which targets the latent state distribution directly, and observation-based selection, which aims at the induced distribution over observations. These formulations differ in how their guarantees work with roll-out methods; notably, observation-based selection may fail under the common Single-Reset roll-out but has guarantees with the less conventional Repeated-Reset approach. The work also discusses practical concerns such as distribution shifts and the influence of sampling policies. Overall, this study uncovers a complex landscape of algorithmic strategies, theoretical subtleties, and open research questions in state resetting for simulators that was previously overlooked.
arXiv:2511.20870v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: State resetting is a fundamental but often overlooked capability of simulators. It supports sample-based planning by allowing resets to previously encountered simulation states, and enables calibration of simulators using real data by resetting to states observed in real-system traces. While often taken for granted, state resetting in complex simulators can be nontrivial: when the simulator comes with latent variables (states), state resetting requires sampling from the posterior over the latent state given the observable history, a.k.a. the belief state (Silver and Veness, 2010). While exact sampling is often infeasible, many approximate belief-state samplers can be constructed, raising the question of how to select among them using only sampling access to the simulator. In this paper, we show that this problem reduces to a general conditional distribution-selection task and develop a new algorithm and analysis under sampling-only access. Building on this reduction, the belief-state selection problem admits two different formulations: latent state-based selection, which directly targets the conditional distribution of the latent state, and observation-based selection, which targets the induced distribution over the observation. Interestingly, these formulations differ in how their guarantees interact with the downstream roll-out methods: perhaps surprisingly, observation-based selection may fail under the most natural roll-out method (which we call Single-Reset) but enjoys guarantees under the less conventional alternative (which we call Repeated-Reset). Together with discussion on issues such as distribution shift and the choice of sampling policies, our paper reveals a rich landscape of algorithmic choices, theoretical nuances, and open questions, in this seemingly simple problem.

item.title: Representation Integrity in Temporal Graph Learning Methods
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: dynamic graphs, representation integrity, embedding evaluation, synthetic scenarios, neural models

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of evaluating dynamic graph embeddings beyond task-specific scores by introducing the concept of representation integrity, which measures how faithfully embeddings reflect changes in the underlying network topology. The authors formalize this notion and develop a family of indexes designed to quantify the alignment between graph changes and the corresponding embedding variations. They test these indexes using three synthetic scenarios—Gradual Merge, Abrupt Move, and Periodic Re-wiring—across forty-two candidates to identify a single recommended metric that meets both theoretical and empirical criteria. This chosen metric consistently ranks the UASE and IPP models as the most stable, confirming their robustness. The study then applies this metric to compare common dynamic graph learning models, revealing that different neural architectures excel in scenario-specific ways. Moreover, the integrity index shows a strong positive correlation with one-step link-prediction AUC, linking embedding quality with predictive performance. Overall, the proposed representation integrity framework provides a task-agnostic, interpretable evaluation tool for dynamic graph embeddings, enabling clearer guidance for model selection and informing future dynamic graph learning architecture design.
arXiv:2511.20873v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Real-world systems ranging from airline routes to cryptocurrency transfers are naturally modelled as dynamic graphs whose topology changes over time. Conventional benchmarks judge dynamic-graph learners by a handful of task-specific scores, yet seldom ask whether the embeddings themselves remain a truthful, interpretable reflection of the evolving network. We formalize this requirement as representation integrity and derive a family of indexes that measure how closely embedding changes follow graph changes. Three synthetic scenarios, Gradual Merge, Abrupt Move, and Periodic Re-wiring, are used to screen forty-two candidate indexes. Based on which we recommend one index that passes all of our theoretical and empirical tests. In particular, this validated metric consistently ranks the provably stable UASE and IPP models highest. We then use this index to do a comparative study on representation integrity of common dynamic graph learning models. This study exposes the scenario-specific strengths of neural methods, and shows a strong positive rank correlation with one-step link-prediction AUC. The proposed integrity framework, therefore, offers a task-agnostic and interpretable evaluation tool for dynamic-graph representation quality, providing more explicit guidance for model selection and future architecture design.

item.title: Probabilistic Hash Embeddings for Online Learning of Categorical Features
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: streaming data, categorical features, probabilistic hash embedding, online learning, Bayesian inference

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of handling streaming data with categorical features whose vocabulary dynamically changes and can grow without bound. Traditional feature hashing methods map categorical values to a fixed-size feature space but are typically designed for batch, offline settings. The authors demonstrate that deterministic embeddings used in online learning are sensitive to the order in which categories arrive and suffer from forgetting, resulting in performance decline. To overcome these limitations, they propose a novel probabilistic hash embedding (PHE) model that treats embeddings as stochastic and incorporates Bayesian online learning to update embeddings incrementally. The paper derives a scalable inference algorithm that efficiently learns model parameters and updates posterior distributions of embeddings and latent variables. Key advantages of the approach include handling evolving vocabularies, adaptability to new items without forgetting previously seen ones, bounded memory requirements independent of the total distinct categories, and invariance to the sequence in which items arrive. Experimental results in classification, sequence modeling, and recommendation system tasks under online learning scenarios demonstrate that PHE outperforms baseline methods while maintaining memory efficiency—using only 2 to 4 times the memory of a one-hot embedding table. Supplementary materials and code are available on GitHub for reproducibility and further investigation.
arXiv:2511.20893v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We study streaming data with categorical features where the vocabulary of categorical feature values is changing and can even grow unboundedly over time. Feature hashing is commonly used as a pre-processing step to map these categorical values into a feature space of fixed size before learning their embeddings. While these methods have been developed and evaluated for offline or batch settings, in this paper we consider online settings. We show that deterministic embeddings are sensitive to the arrival order of categories and suffer from forgetting in online learning, leading to performance deterioration. To mitigate this issue, we propose a probabilistic hash embedding (PHE) model that treats hash embeddings as stochastic and applies Bayesian online learning to learn incrementally from data. Based on the structure of PHE, we derive a scalable inference algorithm to learn model parameters and infer/update the posteriors of hash embeddings and other latent variables. Our algorithm (i) can handle an evolving vocabulary of categorical items, (ii) is adaptive to new items without forgetting old items, (iii) is implementable with a bounded set of parameters that does not grow with the number of distinct observed values on the stream, and (iv) is invariant to the item arrival order. Experiments in classification, sequence modeling, and recommendation systems in online learning setups demonstrate the superior performance of PHE while maintaining high memory efficiency (consumes as low as 2~4 memory of a one-hot embedding table). Supplementary materials are at https://github.com/aodongli/probabilistic-hash-embeddings

item.title: Evolved SampleWeights for Bias Mitigation: Effectiveness Depends on Optimization Objectives
item.content:encoded:
Bias mitigation, reweighting, genetic algorithm, fairness metrics, predictive performance

Summary:
1. This paper addresses the issue of biased predictions in machine learning models trained on real-world data, which may harm marginalized communities. 2. The study focuses on reweighting methods that assign different weights to data points during training to reduce bias. 3. Three weighting strategies are compared: evolved weights using a Genetic Algorithm (GA), weights based only on dataset characteristics, and uniform equal weights for all data points. 4. Model performance is evaluated using two predictive metrics—accuracy and area under the ROC curve—and two fairness metrics—demographic parity difference and subgroup false negative fairness. These metrics also serve as the optimization objectives for the GA. 5. Experiments conducted on eleven publicly available datasets, including two medical datasets, demonstrate that GA-evolved weights can improve trade-offs between fairness and predictive performance compared to the other weighting methods. 6. The benefits of evolved weights are highly dependent on which optimization objectives are chosen during the GA process. 7. Optimizing specifically for accuracy and demographic parity difference yielded the most datasets showing significant improvement in both fairness and predictive performance when using evolved weights.
arXiv:2511.20909v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Machine learning models trained on real-world data may inadvertently make biased predictions that negatively impact marginalized communities. Reweighting is a method that can mitigate such bias in model predictions by assigning a weight to each data point used during model training. In this paper, we compare three methods for generating these weights: (1) evolving them using a Genetic Algorithm (GA), (2) computing them using only dataset characteristics, and (3) assigning equal weights to all data points. Model performance under each strategy was evaluated using paired predictive and fairness metrics, which also served as optimization objectives for the GA during evolution. Specifically, we used two predictive metrics (accuracy and area under the Receiver Operating Characteristic curve) and two fairness metrics (demographic parity difference and subgroup false negative fairness). Using experiments on eleven publicly available datasets (including two medical datasets), we show that evolved sample weights can produce models that achieve better trade-offs between fairness and predictive performance than alternative weighting methods. However, the magnitude of these benefits depends strongly on the choice of optimization objectives. Our experiments reveal that optimizing with accuracy and demographic parity difference metrics yields the largest number of datasets for which evolved weights are significantly better than other weighting strategies in optimizing both objectives.

item.title: Exploring Time-Step Size in Reinforcement Learning for Sepsis Treatment
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: reinforcement learning, sepsis management, time-step size, offline RL, policy evaluation

Summary: This study investigates the impact of different time-step sizes on reinforcement learning (RL) for sepsis management, a crucial healthcare application. Most previous RL approaches have used a fixed 4-hour time-step aggregation for patient data, which may oversimplify patient dynamics and affect policy quality. To address this, the authors empirically compare four time-step sizes: 1, 2, 4, and 8 hours, maintaining an identical offline RL pipeline for fairness. They develop action re-mapping techniques that enable evaluation of policies trained and tested at differing time intervals. Cross-time-step model selection is conducted under two distinct policy learning scenarios. The primary focus is to determine how time-step granularity influences state representation learning, behavior cloning, policy training, and off-policy evaluation performances. Results indicate that the optimal time-step size depends on the learning setup, but policies trained with finer time resolutions (1 and 2 hours) combined with a static behavior policy show superior performance and greater stability overall. This research underscores time-step size as a vital design parameter in offline RL for healthcare, challenging the conventional 4-hour standard and advocating for exploring shorter intervals to better capture patient dynamics and improve treatment strategies.
arXiv:2511.20913v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Existing studies on reinforcement learning (RL) for sepsis management have mostly followed an established problem setup, in which patient data are aggregated into 4-hour time steps. Although concerns have been raised regarding the coarseness of this time-step size, which might distort patient dynamics and lead to suboptimal treatment policies, the extent to which this is a problem in practice remains unexplored. In this work, we conducted empirical experiments for a controlled comparison of four time-step sizes ($\Delta t\!=\!1,2,4,8$ h) on this domain, following an identical offline RL pipeline. To enable a fair comparison across time-step sizes, we designed action re-mapping methods that allow for evaluation of policies on datasets with different time-step sizes, and conducted cross-$\Delta t$ model selections under two policy learning setups. Our goal was to quantify how time-step size influences state representation learning, behavior cloning, policy training, and off-policy evaluation. Our results show that performance trends across $\Delta t$ vary as learning setups change, while policies learned at finer time-step sizes ($\Delta t = 1$ h and $2$ h) using a static behavior policy achieve the overall best performance and stability. Our work highlights time-step size as a core design choice in offline RL for healthcare and provides evidence supporting alternatives beyond the conventional 4-hour setup.

item.title: Operationalizing Quantized Disentanglement
item.content:encoded:
Quantized factors, unsupervised identifiability, axis-aligned discontinuities, density cliffs, disentanglement

Summary: This work addresses the challenge of unsupervised identifiability of quantized latent factors by leveraging recent theoretical insights. The key assumption is that quantization thresholds manifest as axis-aligned discontinuities in the probability density function of latent factors. Building on this, the authors propose a practical criterion to encourage learned mappings to exhibit density profiles with such axis-aligned discontinuities, termed "cliffs." These cliffs represent sharp jumps in estimated factor densities. To capture the theoretical property of independent discontinuities, the method enforces that the location of these cliffs along one factor should remain independent of other factors' values. This approach, named Cliff, operationalizes the high-level theoretical principles into a usable framework for unsupervised disentanglement. Experimental results show that Cliff outperforms existing baseline methods consistently across all standard disentanglement benchmarks. This improvement underscores the effectiveness of incorporating axis-aligned, independent discontinuities as a guiding criterion in unsupervised latent factor disentanglement, particularly under nonlinear transformations. The study thus bridges a critical gap between theoretical identifiability results and practical unsupervised learning applications.
arXiv:2511.20927v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent theoretical work established the unsupervised identifiability of quantized factors under any diffeomorphism. The theory assumes that quantization thresholds correspond to axis-aligned discontinuities in the probability density of the latent factors. By constraining a learned map to have a density with axis-aligned discontinuities, we can recover the quantization of the factors. However, translating this high-level principle into an effective practical criterion remains challenging, especially under nonlinear maps. Here, we develop a criterion for unsupervised disentanglement by encouraging axis-aligned discontinuities. Discontinuities manifest as sharp changes in the estimated density of factors and form what we call cliffs. Following the definition of independent discontinuities from the theory, we encourage the location of the cliffs along a factor to be independent of the values of the other factors. We show that our method, Cliff, outperforms the baselines on all disentanglement benchmarks, demonstrating its effectiveness in unsupervised disentanglement.

item.title: Semantic Superiority vs. Forensic Efficiency: A Comparative Analysis of Deep Learning and Psycholinguistics for Business Email Compromise Detection
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Business Email Compromise, Psycholinguistic Detection, DistilBERT, CatBoost, Cost-sensitive Learning

Summary: This paper addresses Business Email Compromise (BEC), a high-impact social engineering threat causing over $2.9 billion in annual losses as reported by the 2024 FBI Internet Crime Report. It highlights the significant economic asymmetry between the costs of False Negatives (fraud losses) and False Positives (manual reviews), with fraud losses being approximately 5,480 times more costly. Two detection paradigms are studied: the Forensic Psycholinguistic Stream using CatBoost, which offers high interpretability, low latency (0.885 ms), and low computational cost; and the Semantic Stream using DistilBERT, a deep learning model providing superior accuracy (AUC = 1.0000, F1 = 0.9981) at a higher but acceptable latency (7.403 ms) on GPU infrastructure. The dataset employed is adversarially poisoned and generated with the novel Black Hole protocol, with evaluations performed on a Tesla T4 GPU. The results suggest that DistilBERT is ideal for organizations equipped with GPU resources due to superior detection performance, while CatBoost is more suitable for edge or cost-sensitive deployments due to significantly lower latency and resource consumption. Both approaches demonstrate remarkable return on investment exceeding 99.96%, achieved by optimizing cost-sensitive learning strategies to reduce costly False Negatives, thus mitigating financial damages effectively.
arXiv:2511.20944v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Business Email Compromise (BEC) is a sophisticated social engineering threat that manipulates organizational hierarchies and exploits psychological vulnerabilities, leading to significant financial damage. According to the 2024 FBI Internet Crime Report, BEC accounts for over $2.9 billion in annual adjusted losses, presenting significant economic asymmetry: the cost of a False Negative (fraud loss) exceeds the cost of a False Positive (manual review) by orders of magnitude (approximately 1 to 5,480). This paper examines two detection paradigms for BEC: the Forensic Psycholinguistic Stream, which utilizes CatBoost to analyze psycholinguistic cues with high interpretability and low latency, and the Semantic Stream, which employs DistilBERT for deep learning-based contextual language understanding, offering superior accuracy at higher computational cost. We evaluated DistilBERT on an adversarially poisoned dataset (N = 7,990) generated via our Black Hole protocol, benchmarked on Tesla T4 GPU infrastructure, achieving superior detection (AUC = 1.0000, F1 = 0.9981) with acceptable real-time latency (7.403 milliseconds). CatBoost achieves competitive detection (AUC = 0.9905, F1 = 0.9486) at 8.4x lower latency (0.885 milliseconds), consuming negligible computational resources. For organizations with GPU infrastructure, DistilBERT offers superior accuracy. CatBoost is preferable for edge deployments or cost-sensitive environments due to comparable security and lower operational costs. Both approaches demonstrate return on investment exceeding 99.96% when optimized through cost-sensitive learning, by significantly reducing false negatives and associated financial losses.

item.title: Dataset Poisoning Attacks on Behavioral Cloning Policies
item.content:encoded:
Behavior Cloning, backdoor attacks, dataset poisoning, robustness, entropy-based trigger

Summary:

1. This paper analyzes the vulnerability of Behavior Cloning (BC) policies to clean-label backdoor attacks, which inject visual triggers into expert demonstration datasets to create harmful spurious correlations.
2. The study investigates how the effectiveness of these backdoor attacks scales with key factors such as the fraction of poisoned data, trigger strength, and trigger type.
3. A novel entropy-based test-time trigger attack is introduced, targeting critical states during deployment to maximize the degradation of policy performance.
4. Empirical results reveal that even minimally poisoned datasets produce BC policies that maintain near-baseline task performance, masking significant susceptibility to backdoor triggers during real-world use.
5. The findings highlight an urgent need for research focused on improving the robustness of BC policies, especially as they are increasingly trained with large-scale datasets for deployment in cyber-physical systems.

Additional resources including videos and code are provided at the authors' project site.
arXiv:2511.20992v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Behavior Cloning (BC) is a popular framework for training sequential decision policies from expert demonstrations via supervised learning. As these policies are increasingly being deployed in the real world, their robustness and potential vulnerabilities are an important concern. In this work, we perform the first analysis of the efficacy of clean-label backdoor attacks on BC policies. Our backdoor attacks poison a dataset of demonstrations by injecting a visual trigger to create a spurious correlation that can be exploited at test time. We evaluate how policy vulnerability scales with the fraction of poisoned data, the strength of the trigger, and the trigger type. We also introduce a novel entropy-based test-time trigger attack that substantially degrades policy performance by identifying critical states where test-time triggering of the backdoor is expected to be most effective at degrading performance. We empirically demonstrate that BC policies trained on even minimally poisoned datasets exhibit deceptively high, near-baseline task performance despite being highly vulnerable to backdoor trigger attacks during deployment. Our results underscore the urgent need for more research into the robustness of BC policies, particularly as large-scale datasets are increasingly used to train policies for real-world cyber-physical systems. Videos and code are available at https://sites.google.com/view/dataset-poisoning-in-bc.

item.title: Subgoal Graph-Augmented Planning for LLM-Guided Open-World Reinforcement Learning
item.content:encoded:
Large language models, reinforcement learning, subgoal planning, multi-LLM pipeline, subgoal graph

Summary:

This paper addresses the challenge of aligning high-level task plans generated by large language models (LLMs) with executable actions in reinforcement learning (RL) environments. The authors identify two key limitations of single-LLM planning: the generation of semantically plausible but infeasible or contextually irrelevant subgoals due to lack of environment grounding, and unreliable self-verification that causes overconfident yet failing subgoals during execution.
