However, such outcome-driven metrics fail to distinguish whether a modality is inherently informative or whether its value arises only through interaction with other modalities. This distinction is particularly important in cross-attention architectures, where modalities influence each other's representations. In this work, we propose a framework based on Partial Information Decomposition (PID) that quantifies modality contributions by decomposing predictive information in internal embeddings into unique, redundant, and synergistic components. To enable scalable, inference-only analysis, we develop an algorithm based on the Iterative Proportional Fitting Procedure (IPFP) that computes layer and dataset-level contributions without retraining. This provides a principled, representation-level view of multimodal behavior, offering clearer and more interpretable insights than outcome-based metrics.

item.title: PrefixGPT: Prefix Adder Optimization by a Generative Pre-trained Transformer
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Prefix Adders, Transformer, GPT, Hardware Design, Area-Delay Product

Summary: This paper introduces PrefixGPT, a generative pre-trained Transformer model designed to optimize prefix adders, which are crucial components in high-speed compute-intensive applications. Prefix adders pose design challenges due to strict rules and an exponentially large design space. PrefixGPT generates valid prefix adder topologies from scratch by representing them as two-dimensional coordinate sequences and enforcing legality masks during generation to ensure validity by construction. The model employs a customized decoder-only Transformer architecture and undergoes two training stages: pre-training on a dataset of randomly synthesized valid prefix adders to grasp fundamental design principles, followed by fine-tuning focused on optimizing design quality within the large design space. Experimental results show that PrefixGPT discovers new optimal prefix adder designs that improve the area-delay product (ADP) by 7.7% compared to state-of-the-art methods. Moreover, it significantly enhances exploration quality, reducing average ADP by up to 79.1%, which highlights the model’s superior ability to navigate and optimize complex hardware design spaces. This work demonstrates the promising potential of GPT-style models to learn intricate hardware design rules and apply that knowledge to achieve more efficient and optimized hardware architectures.
arXiv:2511.19472v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Prefix adders are widely used in compute-intensive applications for their high speed. However, designing optimized prefix adders is challenging due to strict design rules and an exponentially large design space. We introduce PrefixGPT, a generative pre-trained Transformer (GPT) that directly generates optimized prefix adders from scratch. Our approach represents an adder's topology as a two-dimensional coordinate sequence and applies a legality mask during generation, ensuring every design is valid by construction. PrefixGPT features a customized decoder-only Transformer architecture. The model is first pre-trained on a corpus of randomly synthesized valid prefix adders to learn design rules and then fine-tuned to navigate the design space for optimized design quality. Compared with existing works, PrefixGPT not only finds a new optimal design with a 7.7% improved area-delay product (ADP) but exhibits superior exploration quality, lowering the average ADP by up to 79.1%. This demonstrates the potential of GPT-style models to first master complex hardware design principles and then apply them for more efficient design optimization.

item.title: WavefrontDiffusion: Dynamic Decoding Schedule or Improved Reasoning
item.content:encoded:
Diffusion Language Models, Denoising Strategies, WavefrontDiffusion, Text Generation, Semantic Coherence

Summary:

Diffusion Language Models (DLMs) offer a promising alternative to traditional autoregressive text generation models, largely dependent on their denoising strategies to achieve high-quality outputs. The paper identifies two primary denoising methods: Standard Diffusion and BlockDiffusion. Standard Diffusion applies global denoising without update restrictions, which can prematurely end sequences due to incomplete context resolution. BlockDiffusion, on the other hand, updates fixed-size token blocks sequentially but can disrupt the semantic cohesion and reasoning flow because of its rigid structure. To address these issues, the authors propose WavefrontDiffusion, a novel dynamic decoding technique that advances a wavefront of active tokens outward from finalized tokens. This approach respects the natural semantic structure of text, adapting the update process in a way that preserves coherence. Importantly, WavefrontDiffusion maintains computational costs comparable to block-based methods. Evaluations on four benchmarks related to reasoning and code generation demonstrate that WavefrontDiffusion outperforms existing methods, delivering higher semantic fidelity and more coherent outputs. This work illustrates the significance of adaptive scheduling in diffusion-based language models to enhance both the efficiency and quality of generated text.
arXiv:2511.19473v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Diffusion Language Models (DLMs) have shown strong potential for text generation and are becoming a competitive alternative to autoregressive models. The denoising strategy plays an important role in determining the quality of their outputs. Mainstream denoising strategies include Standard Diffusion and BlockDiffusion. Standard Diffusion performs global denoising without restricting the update range, often finalizing incomplete context and causing premature end-of-sequence predictions. BlockDiffusion updates fixed-size blocks in a preset order, but its rigid structure can break apart coherent semantic units and disrupt reasoning. We present WavefrontDiffusion, a dynamic decoding approach that expands a wavefront of active tokens outward from finalized positions. This adaptive process follows the natural flow of semantic structure while keeping computational cost equal to block-based methods. Across four benchmarks in reasoning and code generation, WavefrontDiffusion achieves state-of-the-art performance while producing outputs with higher semantic fidelity, showing the value of adaptive scheduling for more coherent and efficient generation.

item.title: Exploiting the Experts: Unauthorized Compression in MoE-LLMs
item.content:encoded:
Mixture-of-Experts, Large Language Models, Model Pruning, Expert Attribution, Model Security

Summary: This paper analyzes the vulnerability of Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architectures in large language models (LLMs) with respect to unauthorized compression and fine-tuning. First, the authors introduce an expert attribution framework that identifies which experts within the MoE are most responsible for specific tasks, facilitating targeted analysis. Second, they investigate the performance impact of pruning these identified experts and the importance of re-aligning the remaining experts through active learning-based fine-tuning to recover task accuracy. Third, the study reveals a fundamental trade-off between knowledge loss caused by pruning and the extent of recovery achievable through fine-tuning, emphasizing that pruning alone can significantly degrade task performance. Fourth, based on these findings, they propose defense strategies such as entangled expert training and selective fine-tuning protocols designed to thwart unauthorized compression and adaptation attempts. Finally, the paper frames expert pruning in MoE-LLMs as both a potential attack vector and a defensive opportunity, offering the first systematic framework for secure specialization of MoE-based models against misuse. This dual-use perspective highlights the necessity of designing MoE architectures that balance modular flexibility with robust protection against exploitation.
arXiv:2511.19480v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architectures are increasingly adopted in large language models (LLMs) for their scalability and efficiency. However, their modular structure introduces a unique vulnerability: adversaries can attempt to compress or repurpose models by pruning experts and cheaply fine-tuning the remainder, effectively bypassing licensing and security constraints. In this paper, we systematically study the prunability of MoE-LLMs under task-specific usage. We first develop an expert attribution framework that identifies the subset of experts most responsible for a given task, then evaluate the performance trade-offs of pruning and re-aligning these experts using active learning-driven fine-tuning. Our findings reveal a critical knowledge loss--recovery trade-off: while certain experts can be isolated to retain task accuracy, significant degradation occurs without targeted re-alignment. Based on this analysis, we propose defense strategies that aim to make MoE models harder to compress and fine-tune without authorization, including entangled expert training and selective fine-tuning protocols that resist unauthorized adaptation. By positioning expert pruning as both a threat vector and a defense target, this work highlights the dual-use nature of MoE modularity and provides the first systematic evaluation framework for secure specialization of MoE-LLMs.

item.title: Quality analysis and evaluation prediction of RAG retrieval based on machine learning algorithms
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Retrieval Enhanced Generation, XGBoost, Particle Swarm Optimization, Document Relevance, VMD PSO BiLSTM

Summary: 1. This paper addresses limitations in retrieval enhanced generation (RAG) systems where poor retrieval quality adversely affects the accuracy of generated content. 2. To overcome these challenges, the authors propose an XGBoost machine learning regression model incorporating feature engineering and particle swarm optimization (PSO) to improve processing of tabular features. 3. Correlation analysis reveals a strong positive connection between document relevance and answer quality (correlation coefficient 0.66), implying that enhancing retrieval relevance can significantly boost the quality of generated answers. 4. The study identifies a trade-off among semantic similarity, redundancy, and diversity, with strong negative correlations (-0.89 and -0.88), indicating that increasing semantic similarity and redundancy reduces diversity in results. 5. Experimental comparisons show that the VMD PSO BiLSTM model outperforms other models such as decision trees and AdaBoost across all metrics, demonstrating lower errors (MSE, RMSE, MAE, MAPE) and higher R² scores, indicating better prediction accuracy, stability, and interpretability. Overall, the proposed approach offers an effective path to optimize retrieval quality, thereby enhancing the generation performance of RAG systems, with significant implications for advancing retrieval-based language model applications.
arXiv:2511.19481v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: With the rapid evolution of large language models, retrieval enhanced generation technology has been widely used due to its ability to integrate external knowledge to improve output accuracy. However, the performance of the system is highly dependent on the quality of the retrieval module. If the retrieval results have low relevance to user needs or contain noisy information, it will directly lead to distortion of the generated content. In response to the performance bottleneck of existing models in processing tabular features, this paper proposes an XGBoost machine learning regression model based on feature engineering and particle swarm optimization. Correlation analysis shows that answer_quality is positively correlated with doc_delevance by 0.66, indicating that document relevance has a significant positive effect on answer quality, and improving document relevance may enhance answer quality; The strong negative correlations between semantic similarity, redundancy, and diversity were -0.89 and -0.88, respectively, indicating a trade- off between semantic similarity, redundancy, and diversity. In other words, as the former two increased, diversity significantly decreased. The experimental results comparing decision trees, AdaBoost, etc. show that the VMD PSO BiLSTM model is superior in all evaluation indicators, with significantly lower MSE, RMSE, MAE, and MAPE compared to the comparison model. The R2 value is higher, indicating that its prediction accuracy, stability, and data interpretation ability are more outstanding. This achievement provides an effective path for optimizing the retrieval quality and improving the generation effect of RAG system, and has important value in promoting the implementation and application of related technologies.

item.title: OmniTFT: Omni Target Forecasting for Vital Signs and Laboratory Result Trajectories in Multi Center ICU Data
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: multivariate time-series, vital signs, laboratory results, Temporal Fusion Transformer, ICU forecasting

Summary: This paper introduces OmniTFT, a deep learning framework designed for accurate multivariate time-series prediction of vital signs and laboratory results in intensive care units (ICUs). The challenge addressed involves handling noisy, rapidly fluctuating vital signs and sparse, delayed, or biased laboratory test data. OmniTFT builds upon the Temporal Fusion Transformer (TFT) architecture and incorporates four novel strategies to enhance forecasting performance: sliding window equalized sampling to balance different physiological states, frequency-aware embedding shrinkage to stabilize representations of rare classes, hierarchical variable selection to focus model attention on informative feature clusters, and influence-aligned attention calibration to maintain robustness amid sudden physiological changes. By minimizing dependence on target-specific models and excessive feature engineering, OmniTFT supports unified prediction of diverse clinical variables while fostering generalizability across institutions. The model was evaluated on multiple large ICU datasets (MIMIC-III, MIMIC-IV, and eICU) and demonstrated substantial improvements in forecasting both vital signs and laboratory measurements. Additionally, the attention mechanisms in OmniTFT offer interpretable insights consistent with medical knowledge, highlighting its potential application for quantitative, data-driven clinical decision support in critical care settings.
arXiv:2511.19485v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Accurate multivariate time-series prediction of vital signs and laboratory results is crucial for early intervention and precision medicine in intensive care units (ICUs). However, vital signs are often noisy and exhibit rapid fluctuations, while laboratory tests suffer from missing values, measurement lags, and device-specific bias, making integrative forecasting highly challenging. To address these issues, we propose OmniTFT, a deep learning framework that jointly learns and forecasts high-frequency vital signs and sparsely sampled laboratory results based on the Temporal Fusion Transformer (TFT). Specifically, OmniTFT implements four novel strategies to enhance performance: sliding window equalized sampling to balance physiological states, frequency-aware embedding shrinkage to stabilize rare-class representations, hierarchical variable selection to guide model attention toward informative feature clusters, and influence-aligned attention calibration to enhance robustness during abrupt physiological changes. By reducing the reliance on target-specific architectures and extensive feature engineering, OmniTFT enables unified modeling of multiple heterogeneous clinical targets while preserving cross-institutional generalizability. Across forecasting tasks, OmniTFT achieves substantial performance improvement for both vital signs and laboratory results on the MIMIC-III, MIMIC-IV, and eICU datasets. Its attention patterns are interpretable and consistent with known pathophysiology, underscoring its potential utility for quantitative decision support in clinical care.

item.title: Efficient Inference Using Large Language Models with Limited Human Data: Fine-Tuning then Rectification
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, fine-tuning, rectification, prediction error variance, empirical scaling laws

Summary: This paper addresses enhancing the performance of large language models (LLMs) in social science and market research contexts by combining two main improvement techniques: fine-tuning and rectification. Fine-tuning adjusts LLM predictions to align better with human responses, while rectification corrects biases in those outputs. Unlike traditional methods focused on minimizing mean squared error, the authors propose minimizing the variance of prediction errors during fine-tuning, optimizing the process for the subsequent rectification stage. The study introduces a data-driven framework that strategically allocates a limited number of labeled samples between fine-tuning and rectification using empirical scaling laws. This optimal sample split aims to improve downstream inference and estimation accuracy. Empirical validation shows that this combined and optimally balanced approach outperforms using fine-tuning or rectification independently. The findings suggest that minimizing variance in fine-tuning can lead to better rectified outputs and demonstrate practical advances in leveraging LLMs for improved social science data analysis. This framework provides a new methodological direction for improving LLM-based prediction tasks with limited labeled data.
arXiv:2511.19486v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Driven by recent advances in artificial intelligence (AI), a growing body of work demonstrates the potential of using large language models (LLMs) to generate human-like responses in market research and social science applications. Two primary approaches can be applied to improve the performance of LLMs: fine-tuning, which aligns LLM predictions more closely with human responses, and rectification, which corrects biases in LLM outputs. In this paper, we develop a framework that combines fine-tuning and rectification, and optimally allocates limited labeled samples across the two stages. Unlike the conventional objective that minimizes the mean squared prediction errors, we propose to minimize the variance of the prediction errors as the fine-tuning objective, which is optimal for the downstream rectification stage. Building on this insight, we leverage empirical scaling laws to develop a data-driven method for optimally splitting samples between the fine-tuning and rectification stages. Empirical analysis validates our framework, demonstrating improved estimation and inference performance compared to using either fine-tuning or rectification alone.

item.title: The Generalized Proximity Forest
item.content:encoded:
Random Forest, Proximity Forest, distance-based learning, regression, meta-learning

Summary:

This article focuses on enhancing the utility of Random Forest (RF) proximities, which are useful in various supervised machine learning tasks such as outlier detection, missing data imputation, and visualization. Recognizing that the RF model is not always optimal, the authors build on previous extensions of RF proximities to time series through the Proximity Forest (PF) model. They introduce a generalized PF model that extends RF proximities beyond time series to any supervised distance-based machine learning domain. Furthermore, a new variant of the PF model is proposed specifically for regression tasks, broadening the range of applications. The work also presents the idea of employing the generalized PF model as a meta-learning framework, which enables the extension of supervised imputation capabilities to any pre-trained classifier. Experimental results demonstrate that the generalized PF model offers unique advantages over both the traditional RF model and the k-nearest neighbors model, indicating improved performance and flexibility. This approach effectively combines distance-based learning with the strengths of RF proximities, offering a powerful tool for diverse supervised learning contexts.
arXiv:2511.19487v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent work has demonstrated the utility of Random Forest (RF) proximities for various supervised machine learning tasks, including outlier detection, missing data imputation, and visualization. However, the utility of the RF proximities depends upon the success of the RF model, which itself is not the ideal model in all contexts. RF proximities have recently been extended to time series by means of the distance-based Proximity Forest (PF) model, among others, affording time series analysis with the benefits of RF proximities. In this work, we introduce the generalized PF model, thereby extending RF proximities to all contexts in which supervised distance-based machine learning can occur. Additionally, we introduce a variant of the PF model for regression tasks. We also introduce the notion of using the generalized PF model as a meta-learning framework, extending supervised imputation capability to any pre-trained classifier. We experimentally demonstrate the unique advantages of the generalized PF model compared with both the RF model and the $k$-nearest neighbors model.

item.title: Generative Model-Aided Continual Learning for CSI Feedback in FDD mMIMO-OFDM Systems
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Deep autoencoder, CSI feedback, continual learning, generative adversarial network, mMIMO OFDM

Summary:

This article addresses the challenge of efficient channel state information (CSI) feedback in massive multiple-input multiple-output (mMIMO) orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) systems using deep autoencoder (DAE) frameworks. While DAEs reduce CSI feedback overhead effectively, they struggle to adapt in dynamic environments caused by user mobility, necessitating retraining when new CSI distributions appear, and they suffer from catastrophic forgetting when revisiting previous environments. To overcome these issues, the authors propose a novel generative adversarial network (GAN)-based learning approach for CSI feedback. The GAN generator functions as a memory unit that retains knowledge from past environments, allowing the model to continually learn new information without losing performance on older tasks. This approach enhances the generalization capability of the DAE framework across diverse scenarios and maintains low memory overhead. Additionally, the method can be easily integrated with other advanced CSI feedback models, underlining its robustness and adaptability for practical deployment in dynamic wireless communication systems. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed method in maintaining consistent, high-quality CSI feedback across changing environments.
arXiv:2511.19490v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Deep autoencoder (DAE) frameworks have demonstrated their effectiveness in reducing channel state information (CSI) feedback overhead in massive multiple-input multiple-output (mMIMO) orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) systems. However, existing CSI feedback models struggle to adapt to dynamic environments caused by user mobility, requiring retraining when encountering new CSI distributions. Moreover, returning to previously encountered environments often leads to performance degradation due to catastrophic forgetting. Continual learning involves enabling models to incorporate new information while maintaining performance on previously learned tasks. To address these challenges, we propose a generative adversarial network (GAN)-based learning approach for CSI feedback. By using a GAN generator as a memory unit, our method preserves knowledge from past environments and ensures consistently high performance across diverse scenarios without forgetting. Simulation results show that the proposed approach enhances the generalization capability of the DAE framework while maintaining low memory overhead. Furthermore, it can be seamlessly integrated with other advanced CSI feedback models, highlighting its robustness and adaptability.

item.title: OpenCML: End-to-End Framework of Open-world Machine Learning to Learn Unknown Classes Incrementally
item.content:encoded:
Open-world learning, continual learning, class discovery, incremental learning, artificial intelligence

Summary: Open-world machine learning addresses the limitations of traditional machine learning models that rely on closed-world assumptions, which restrict their ability to retain and build upon previously learned knowledge when encountering new tasks. The proposed model introduces two interconnected tasks to operate in an open and continuous learning environment. First, it identifies and creates novel classes from unknown data, allowing the system to expand its knowledge base. Second, the model incrementally learns to classify new classes as they are discovered, enabling continual improvement over time. This dual approach facilitates ongoing learning and adaptation to new information, reflecting more realistic AI deployment scenarios. The model not only supports open-world learning by discovering unknown classes but also excels in continuous class incremental learning. Experimental results demonstrate that the model outperforms existing open-world learning approaches, achieving a highest average accuracy of 82.54% across four learning iterations. Furthermore, it maintains robust performance with a minimum accuracy of 65.87%, indicating strong generalization and stability in dynamic learning environments. This advancement showcases the model's potential for practical AI applications requiring ongoing learning and flexibility.
arXiv:2511.19491v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Open-world machine learning is an emerging technique in artificial intelligence, where conventional machine learning models often follow closed-world assumptions, which can hinder their ability to retain previously learned knowledge for future tasks. However, automated intelligence systems must learn about novel classes and previously known tasks. The proposed model offers novel learning classes in an open and continuous learning environment. It consists of two different but connected tasks. First, it discovers unknown classes in the data and creates novel classes; next, it learns how to perform class incrementally for each new class. Together, they enable continual learning, allowing the system to expand its understanding of the data and improve over time. The proposed model also outperformed existing approaches in open-world learning. Furthermore, it demonstrated strong performance in continuous learning, achieving a highest average accuracy of 82.54% over four iterations and a minimum accuracy of 65.87%.

item.title: RFX: High-Performance Random Forests with GPU Acceleration and QLORA Compression
item.content:encoded:
Random Forest, proximity matrix, QLORA compression, GPU acceleration, classification

Summary: RFX (Random Forests X) v1.0 is a production-ready Python implementation of Breiman and Cutler's Random Forest classification, featuring comprehensive functionality such as out-of-bag error estimation, overall and local importance measures, proximity matrices with QLORA compression, case-wise analysis, and interactive visualization with CPU and GPU acceleration. It introduces four key solutions to overcome the proximity matrix memory bottleneck, which historically limited Random Forest analysis to about 60,000 samples: (1) QLORA compression drastically reduces GPU proximity matrix memory from 80GB to 6.4MB for 100k samples while preserving 99% of geometric structure, (2) CPU TriBlock proximity method reduces memory by 2.7x with lossless quality via upper-triangle storage and block-sparse thresholding, (3) SM-aware GPU batch sizing optimizes GPU utilization up to 95%, and (4) GPU-accelerated 3D MDS visualization computes embeddings efficiently using power iteration on low-rank factors. Validation across GPU and CPU modes confirms correct implementation and performance, with GPU providing a 1.4x speedup for importance computations with over 500 trees. Proximity calculations scale efficiently from 1,000 up to over 200,000 samples using GPU QLORA, complemented by CPU TriBlock methods for medium-sized datasets (10K-50K samples). Thus, RFX v1.0 removes the proximity memory bottleneck, enabling large-scale proximity-based Random Forest analyses well beyond previous limits while maintaining fidelity and offering open-source production-ready classification.
arXiv:2511.19493v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: RFX (Random Forests X), where X stands for compression or quantization, presents a production-ready implementation of Breiman and Cutler's Random Forest classification methodology in Python. RFX v1.0 provides complete classification: out-of-bag error estimation, overall and local importance measures, proximity matrices with QLORA compression, case-wise analysis, and interactive visualization (rfviz)--all with CPU and GPU acceleration. Regression, unsupervised learning, CLIQUE importance, and RF-GAP proximity are planned for v2.0. This work introduces four solutions addressing the proximity matrix memory bottleneck limiting Random Forest analysis to ~60,000 samples: (1) QLORA (Quantized Low-Rank Adaptation) compression for GPU proximity matrices, reducing memory from 80GB to 6.4MB for 100k samples (12,500x compression with INT8 quantization) while maintaining 99% geometric structure preservation, (2) CPU TriBlock proximity--combining upper-triangle storage with block-sparse thresholding--achieving 2.7x memory reduction with lossless quality, (3) SM-aware GPU batch sizing achieving 95% GPU utilization, and (4) GPU-accelerated 3D MDS visualization computing embeddings directly from low-rank factors using power iteration. Validation across four implementation modes (GPU/CPU x case-wise/non-case-wise) demonstrates correct implementation. GPU achieves 1.4x speedup over CPU for overall importance with 500+ trees. Proximity computation scales from 1,000 to 200,000+ samples (requiring GPU QLORA), with CPU TriBlock filling the gap for medium-scale datasets (10K-50K samples). RFX v1.0 eliminates the proximity memory bottleneck, enabling proximity-based Random Forest analysis on datasets orders of magnitude larger than previously feasible. Open-source production-ready classification following Breiman and Cutler's original methodology.

item.title: A Systematic Study of Compression Ordering for Large Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large Language Models, model compression, knowledge distillation, pruning, quantization

Summary: This paper investigates the combined effects and optimal ordering of three major model compression techniques—knowledge distillation, structured pruning, and low-bit quantization—when applied to the Qwen2.5 3B large language model. The authors evaluate multiple compression pipelines using metrics such as perplexity, G-Eval, clarity, prompt alignment, and compression ratio. Their results confirm that quantization offers the highest standalone compression ratio, while pruning results in moderate quality loss. Crucially, the order in which these techniques are applied significantly impacts overall model quality. The pipeline ordering pruning first, followed by knowledge distillation, and finally quantization (P-KD-Q) is shown to achieve the best balance between compression ratio (3.68x) and model performance, preserving strong instruction-following and language understanding capabilities. Applying quantization too early causes irreversible information loss, which damages later training procedures. This work provides valuable, practical guidance for designing effective, ordering-aware compression strategies, enabling the deployment of LLMs in resource-constrained environments while maintaining acceptable quality.
arXiv:2511.19495v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) require substantial computational resources, making model compression essential for efficient deployment in constrained environments. Among the dominant compression techniques: knowledge distillation, structured pruning, and low-bit quantization, their individual effects are well studied, but their interactions and optimal sequencing remain unclear. This work systematically examines how these techniques perform both independently and in combination when applied to the Qwen2.5 3B model. We evaluate multiple compression pipelines, including single, and proposed three-technique sequences, using perplexity, G-Eval, clarity, prompt alignment, and compression ratio as metrics. Our experiments show that quantization provides the greatest standalone compression, while pruning introduces moderate quality degradation. Critically, the ordering of techniques significantly affects the final model quality: the sequence Pruning, Knowledge Distillation, Quantization (P-KD-Q) yields the best balance, achieving a 3.68x compression ratio while preserving strong instruction-following and language understanding capabilities. Conversely, pipelines applying quantization early suffer severe performance degradation due to irreversible information loss that impairs subsequent training. Overall, this study offers practical insight into designing effective, ordering-aware compression pipelines for deploying LLMs in resource-limited settings.

item.title: Xmodel-2.5: 1.3B Data-Efficient Reasoning SLM
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: small language model, maximal-update parameterization, Muon optimizer, curriculum training, FP8-mixed-precision

Summary: The paper introduces Xmodel-2.5, a 1.3-billion-parameter small language model optimized for edge and cost-sensitive scenarios while maintaining strong reasoning and tool-use capabilities. The model leverages maximal-update parameterization (μP), which enables hyper-parameters calibrated on a smaller 20M-parameter proxy model to directly transfer to the full-scale 1.3B model, even under a parameter-tied tie-word-embedding architecture. The training follows a three-phase curriculum named Warmup--Stable--Decay with a large-scale 1.4 trillion token dataset. Additionally, the authors demonstrate that switching optimizers from AdamW to Muon during the decay phase improves average performance on a 13-task reasoning benchmark by 4.58% without changing other hyper-parameters, effectively combining the stability benefits of AdamW in early training with the sharpening advantages of Muon later on. The training also employs FP8 mixed precision to achieve an optimal balance between computational throughput and model accuracy. The research is accompanied by the release of all model checkpoints, training recipes, and evaluation code publicly under the Apache-2.0 license, providing resources for reproducibility and further exploration. Links to the model and code repository are provided for community use.
arXiv:2511.19496v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models deliver strong reasoning and tool-use skills, yet their computational demands make them impractical for edge or cost-sensitive deployments. We present \textbf{Xmodel-2.5}, a 1.3-billion-parameter small language model designed as a \emph{drop-in agent core}. Training with maximal-update parameterization ($\mu$P) allows hyper-parameters tuned on a 20M-parameter proxy to transfer directly to the full model, even under the parameter-tied \emph{tie-word-embedding} architecture. A 1.4T-token Warmup--Stable--Decay curriculum is used, and we further show that \textbf{switching from AdamW to Muon during the decay phase} improves the 13-task reasoning average by 4.58\,\% while keeping every other hyper-parameter fixed, verifying that early AdamW stability can be paired with late Muon sharpening for better downstream performance. FP8-mixed-precision training balances accuracy and throughput. All checkpoints, recipes, and evaluation code are released under the Apache-2.0 license.\footnote{https://huggingface.co/XiaoduoAILab/Xmodel-2.5 and https://huggingface.co/XiaoduoAILab/Xmodel-2.5-history (training checkpoints).} Training code and evaluation harness: https://github.com/XiaoduoAILab/Xmodel-2.5.

item.title: PeriodNet: Boosting the Potential of Attention Mechanism for Time Series Forecasting
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: PeriodNet, attention mechanism, time series forecasting, sparse period attention, iterative grouping mechanism

Summary:

The paper introduces PeriodNet, a novel network architecture designed to improve time series forecasting (TSF) for both univariate and multivariate data. It highlights the limitations of traditional attention mechanisms, such as those used in BERT and GPT, for TSF tasks, motivating the need for more specialized structures. PeriodNet incorporates period attention and a sparse period attention mechanism to effectively analyze adjacent periods, thereby enhancing the extraction of local features, periodic patterns, and global dependencies within the data. To address cross-variable redundancy in multivariate TSF, an iterative grouping mechanism is proposed, which efficiently reduces redundant information across variables. The authors redesign the conventional Transformer’s architecture by introducing a period diffuser to enable accurate multi-period predictions, optimizing the use of features extracted on the encoder side. Extensive experiments on eight benchmark datasets demonstrate that PeriodNet outperforms six state-of-the-art time series forecasting models in terms of mean square error (MSE) and mean absolute error (MAE). Notably, PeriodNet achieves a 22% relative improvement in forecasting accuracy for long time series of length 720 compared to traditional encoder-decoder Transformer-based models, demonstrating its superiority and potential for broad applications in TSF.
arXiv:2511.19497v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The attention mechanism has demonstrated remarkable potential in sequence modeling, exemplified by its successful application in natural language processing with models such as Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT) and Generative Pre-trained Transformer (GPT). Despite these advancements, its utilization in time series forecasting (TSF) has yet to meet expectations. Exploring a better network structure for attention in TSF holds immense significance across various domains. In this paper, we present PeriodNet with a brand new structure to forecast univariate and multivariate time series. PeriodNet incorporates period attention and sparse period attention mechanism for analyzing adjacent periods. It enhances the mining of local characteristics, periodic patterns, and global dependencies. For efficient cross-variable modeling, we introduce an iterative grouping mechanism which can directly reduce the cross-variable redundancy. To fully leverage the extracted features on the encoder side, we redesign the entire architecture of the vanilla Transformer and propose a period diffuser for precise multi-period prediction. Through comprehensive experiments conducted on eight datasets, we demonstrate that PeriodNet outperforms six state-of-the-art models in both univariate and multivariate TSF scenarios in terms of mean square error and mean absolute error. In particular, PeriodNet achieves a relative improvement of 22% when forecasting time series with a length of 720, in comparison to other models based on the conventional encoder-decoder Transformer architecture.

item.title: Hierarchical Dual-Strategy Unlearning for Biomedical and Healthcare Intelligence Using Imperfect and Privacy-Sensitive Medical Data
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, selective knowledge unlearning, medical concept hierarchy, privacy, healthcare

Summary: This paper addresses privacy concerns in large language models (LLMs), particularly in healthcare applications where sensitive patient information can be memorized during training. The authors propose a hierarchical dual-strategy framework designed for selective knowledge unlearning, enabling the precise removal of specialized or private medical knowledge without compromising the model’s core medical capabilities. The methodology integrates two main techniques: geometric-constrained gradient updates that selectively adjust only the target parameters involved, and concept-aware token-level interventions informed by a unified four-level medical concept hierarchy. This hierarchical approach differentiates between tokens critical for knowledge preservation and tokens targeted for unlearning. The framework is evaluated on two medical QA datasets—MedMCQA (surgical domain) and MHQA (mental health domain focusing on anxiety, depression, trauma)—demonstrating impressive results with an 82.7% forgetting rate of targeted knowledge and an 88.5% preservation rate of essential medical knowledge. Importantly, this approach modifies only 0.1% of the model parameters, ensuring efficiency and minimal disruption. The framework also upholds strong privacy guarantees, which are significant for compliance with healthcare regulations, auditability, and ethical standards in clinical research involving LLMs.
arXiv:2511.19498v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) exhibit exceptional performance but pose substantial privacy risks due to training data memorization, particularly within healthcare contexts involving imperfect or privacy-sensitive patient information. We present a hierarchical dual-strategy framework for selective knowledge unlearning that precisely removes specialized knowledge while preserving fundamental medical competencies. Our approach synergistically integrates geometric-constrained gradient updates to selectively modulate target parameters with concept-aware token-level interventions that distinguish between preservation-critical and unlearning-targeted tokens via a unified four-level medical concept hierarchy. Comprehensive evaluations on the MedMCQA (surgical) and MHQA (anxiety, depression, trauma) datasets demonstrate superior performance, achieving an 82.7% forgetting rate and 88.5% knowledge preservation. Notably, our framework maintains robust privacy guarantees while requiring modification of only 0.1% of parameters, addressing critical needs for regulatory compliance, auditability, and ethical standards in clinical research.

item.title: Beyond Binary Classification: A Semi-supervised Approach to Generalized AI-generated Image Detection
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: generative models, GANs, diffusion models, synthetic image detection, cross-generator generalization

Summary:

1. Recent advances in generative models such as StyleGAN, Midjourney, and DALL-E have created highly realistic synthetic images, raising challenges for verifying digital media authenticity.
2. The main architectures behind these generators are Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) and Diffusion Models (DMs), which produce different types of artifacts.
3. Current forensic detectors struggle to generalize well across different generator types, especially when switching between GANs and DMs.
4. The authors analyze theoretically how GANs often lead to partial manifold coverage, causing boundary artifacts, while DMs produce complete coverage that results in over-smoothing.
5. Inspired by this, they introduce the Triarchy Detector (TriDetect), a semi-supervised method that improves binary classification by discovering latent architectural differences in fake images.
6. TriDetect uses balanced cluster assignment through the Sinkhorn-Knopp algorithm and a cross-view consistency mechanism to learn fundamental architectural distinctions.
7. Experiments on two standard benchmarks and three real-world datasets, compared against 13 baselines, show that TriDetect generalizes effectively to unseen generators.
arXiv:2511.19499v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The rapid advancement of generators (e.g., StyleGAN, Midjourney, DALL-E) has produced highly realistic synthetic images, posing significant challenges to digital media authenticity. These generators are typically based on a few core architectural families, primarily Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) and Diffusion Models (DMs). A critical vulnerability in current forensics is the failure of detectors to achieve cross-generator generalization, especially when crossing architectural boundaries (e.g., from GANs to DMs). We hypothesize that this gap stems from fundamental differences in the artifacts produced by these \textbf{distinct architectures}. In this work, we provide a theoretical analysis explaining how the distinct optimization objectives of the GAN and DM architectures lead to different manifold coverage behaviors. We demonstrate that GANs permit partial coverage, often leading to boundary artifacts, while DMs enforce complete coverage, resulting in over-smoothing patterns. Motivated by this analysis, we propose the \textbf{Tri}archy \textbf{Detect}or (TriDetect), a semi-supervised approach that enhances binary classification by discovering latent architectural patterns within the "fake" class. TriDetect employs balanced cluster assignment via the Sinkhorn-Knopp algorithm and a cross-view consistency mechanism, encouraging the model to learn fundamental architectural distincts. We evaluate our approach on two standard benchmarks and three in-the-wild datasets against 13 baselines to demonstrate its generalization capability to unseen generators.

item.title: Position: The Complexity of Perfect AI Alignment -- Formalizing the RLHF Trilemma
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback, Alignment Trilemma, Representativeness, Robustness, Computational Complexity

Summary:

This paper formalizes a key challenge in aligning large language models through Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF), termed the Alignment Trilemma. The trilemma states that no RLHF system can simultaneously achieve (i) high representativeness across diverse human value systems, (ii) polynomial-time computational tractability, and (iii) robustness against adversarial perturbations and distribution shifts. By combining statistical learning theory with robust optimization, the authors prove that achieving strong representativeness (ε ≤ 0.01) and robustness (δ ≤ 0.001) for global-scale populations necessitates super-polynomial computational resources exponential in the dimensionality of context, specifically at least on the order of 2^(d_context). Current RLHF implementations circumvent this trilemma by limiting representativeness, using relatively small and homogeneous annotator pools (around 10^3 to 10^4 samples), whereas accurate global representation would require orders of magnitude larger data (~10^7 to 10^8 samples). This framework explains typical RLHF issues such as preference collapse, sycophancy, and amplification of majority biases. The paper concludes by suggesting strategic relaxations of alignment objectives as practical paths forward to balance these fundamental trade-offs in RLHF systems.
arXiv:2511.19504v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF) is widely used for aligning large language models, yet practitioners face a persistent puzzle: improving safety often reduces fairness, scaling to diverse populations becomes computationally intractable, and making systems robust often amplifies majority biases. We formalize this tension as the Alignment Trilemma: no RLHF system can simultaneously achieve (i) epsilon-representativeness across diverse human values, (ii) polynomial tractability in sample and compute complexity, and (iii) delta-robustness against adversarial perturbations and distribution shift. Through a complexity-theoretic analysis integrating statistical learning theory and robust optimization, we prove that achieving both representativeness (epsilon <= 0.01) and robustness (delta <= 0.001) for global-scale populations requires Omega(2^{d_context}) operations, which is super-polynomial in the context dimensionality. We show that current RLHF implementations resolve this trilemma by sacrificing representativeness: they collect only 10^3--10^4 samples from homogeneous annotator pools while 10^7--10^8 samples are needed for true global representation. Our framework provides a unified explanation for documented RLHF pathologies including preference collapse, sycophancy, and systematic bias amplification. We conclude with concrete directions for navigating these fundamental trade-offs through strategic relaxations of alignment requirements.

item.title: Profile Generators: A Link between the Narrative and the Binary Matrix Representation
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: cognitive disorders, DSM-5, symptom profile generator, binary matrix, MPCS algorithm

Summary:

This study addresses challenges in representing mental health cognitive disorders from the DSM-5 in a machine-actionable way. Traditional binary matrix approaches to calculate symptom similarity become infeasible due to the exponential number of symptom combinations. To overcome this, the authors introduce a new format called the symptom profile generator. This generator uses a structured format of lists, sets, and numbers to represent complex diagnostic criteria and symptom pathways more efficiently and readably. The approach facilitates automated generation of valid symptom profiles and represents disorders as lists of generators instead of enormous binary matrices. The paper demonstrates the limitations of binary matrices in managing complex psychotic disorders, showing that existing similarity algorithms, such as the Maximum Pairwise Cosine Similarity (MPCS), cannot handle such large matrices. Consequently, the researchers develop a profile reduction method through targeted manipulation of generators to calculate specific MPCS values between disorders. This novel generator framework enables easier creation of binary representations for large datasets and supports similarity calculations in complex diagnostic scenarios where traditional methods fail. The result is a comprehensive, adaptable, and scalable alternative to matrix-based symptom representation for cognitive disorders.
arXiv:2511.19506v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Mental health disorders, particularly cognitive disorders defined by deficits in cognitive abilities, are described in detail in the DSM-5, which includes definitions and examples of signs and symptoms. A simplified, machine-actionable representation was developed to assess the similarity and separability of these disorders, but it is not suited for the most complex cases. Generating or applying a full binary matrix for similarity calculations is infeasible due to the vast number of symptom combinations. This research develops an alternative representation that links the narrative form of the DSM-5 with the binary matrix representation and enables automated generation of valid symptom combinations. Using a strict pre-defined format of lists, sets, and numbers with slight variations, complex diagnostic pathways involving numerous symptom combinations can be represented. This format, called the symptom profile generator (or simply generator), provides a readable, adaptable, and comprehensive alternative to a binary matrix while enabling easy generation of symptom combinations (profiles). Cognitive disorders, which typically involve multiple diagnostic criteria with several symptoms, can thus be expressed as lists of generators. Representing several psychotic disorders in generator form and generating all symptom combinations showed that matrix representations of complex disorders become too large to manage. The MPCS (maximum pairwise cosine similarity) algorithm cannot handle matrices of this size, prompting the development of a profile reduction method using targeted generator manipulation to find specific MPCS values between disorders. The generators allow easier creation of binary representations for large matrices and make it possible to calculate specific MPCS cases between complex disorders through conditional generators.

item.title: TouchFormer: A Robust Transformer-based Framework for Multimodal Material Perception
item.content:encoded:
multimodal fusion, material perception, Modality-Adaptive Gating, Cross-Instance Embedding Regularization, robotic applications

Summary:

1. Traditional vision-based material perception methods often suffer performance degradation under visually impaired conditions, motivating the shift toward non-visual multimodal approaches.
2. Existing multimodal fusion techniques typically perform naive integration of inputs, ignoring challenges such as modality-specific noise, missing modalities, and varying importance of different sensory inputs.
3. The paper introduces TouchFormer, a robust multimodal fusion framework that employs a Modality-Adaptive Gating (MAG) mechanism alongside intra- and inter-modality attention to adaptively integrate cross-modal features and improve robustness.
4. Additionally, TouchFormer incorporates a Cross-Instance Embedding Regularization (CER) strategy to significantly enhance classification accuracy for fine-grained material subcategory recognition.
5. Experiments on benchmark datasets (SSMC and USMC) show that TouchFormer achieves accuracy improvements of 2.48% and 6.83% respectively compared to existing non-visual methods.
6. Real-world robotic experiments further validate TouchFormer’s effectiveness, demonstrating improved environmental perception for robots.
7. This advancement has implications for deployment in safety-critical scenarios such as emergency response and industrial automation.
8. The authors plan to open-source the code and datasets, with supplementary videos provided to showcase results.
arXiv:2511.19509v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Traditional vision-based material perception methods often experience substantial performance degradation under visually impaired conditions, thereby motivating the shift toward non-visual multimodal material perception. Despite this, existing approaches frequently perform naive fusion of multimodal inputs, overlooking key challenges such as modality-specific noise, missing modalities common in real-world scenarios, and the dynamically varying importance of each modality depending on the task. These limitations lead to suboptimal performance across several benchmark tasks. In this paper, we propose a robust multimodal fusion framework, TouchFormer. Specifically, we employ a Modality-Adaptive Gating (MAG) mechanism and intra- and inter-modality attention mechanisms to adaptively integrate cross-modal features, enhancing model robustness. Additionally, we introduce a Cross-Instance Embedding Regularization(CER) strategy, which significantly improves classification accuracy in fine-grained subcategory material recognition tasks. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared to existing non-visual methods, the proposed TouchFormer framework achieves classification accuracy improvements of 2.48% and 6.83% on SSMC and USMC tasks, respectively. Furthermore, real-world robotic experiments validate TouchFormer's effectiveness in enabling robots to better perceive and interpret their environment, paving the way for its deployment in safety-critical applications such as emergency response and industrial automation. The code and datasets will be open-source, and the videos are available in the supplementary materials.

item.title: Row-stochastic matrices can provably outperform doubly stochastic matrices in decentralized learning
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: decentralized learning, weighted loss, row-stochastic matrix, Hilbert space, convergence rates

Summary:
1. The paper addresses decentralized learning with heterogeneous node weights \(\lambda\) in the global loss function, focusing on two strategies: embedding weights into local losses for uniform weights (yielding a doubly stochastic matrix), and keeping original losses with a \(\lambda\)-induced row-stochastic matrix.
2. Although both approaches share the same expected descent direction, prior Euclidean-based analyses leave it unclear whether their convergence guarantees are tight or what fundamentally drives their differences.
3. To resolve this, the authors introduce a weighted Hilbert-space framework \(L^2(\lambda;\mathbb{R}^d)\), which provides strictly tighter convergence rate bounds compared to Euclidean analysis.
4. In the weighted geometry, the row-stochastic matrix becomes self-adjoint, whereas the doubly stochastic matrix does not; this leads to additional penalty terms in the doubly stochastic case, amplifying consensus errors and slowing convergence.
5. The study derives sufficient conditions and topology-based criteria showing that the row-stochastic design can converge faster despite having a smaller spectral gap, offering practical guidelines for network topology design in decentralized learning systems.
arXiv:2511.19513v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Decentralized learning often involves a weighted global loss with heterogeneous node weights $\lambda$. We revisit two natural strategies for incorporating these weights: (i) embedding them into the local losses to retain a uniform weight (and thus a doubly stochastic matrix), and (ii) keeping the original losses while employing a $\lambda$-induced row-stochastic matrix. Although prior work shows that both strategies yield the same expected descent direction for the global loss, it remains unclear whether the Euclidean-space guarantees are tight and what fundamentally differentiates their behaviors. To clarify this, we develop a weighted Hilbert-space framework $L^2(\lambda;\mathbb{R}^d)$ and obtain convergence rates that are strictly tighter than those from Euclidean analysis. In this geometry, the row-stochastic matrix becomes self-adjoint whereas the doubly stochastic one does not, creating additional penalty terms that amplify consensus error, thereby slowing convergence. Consequently, the difference in convergence arises not only from spectral gaps but also from these penalty terms. We then derive sufficient conditions under which the row-stochastic design converges faster even with a smaller spectral gap. Finally, by using a Rayleigh-quotient and Loewner-order eigenvalue comparison, we further obtain topology conditions that guarantee this advantage and yield practical topology-design guidelines.

item.title: Automating Deception: Scalable Multi-Turn LLM Jailbreaks
item.content:encoded:
Multi-turn conversational attacks, Foot-in-the-Door (FITD), jailbreak datasets, Attack Success Rates (ASR), Large Language Models (LLMs)

Summary: 1. The paper addresses multi-turn conversational attacks on Large Language Models (LLMs), which use psychological techniques like the Foot-in-the-Door (FITD) method to bypass safety measures by starting with small requests leading to larger harmful ones. 2. Existing defenses rely on manually created datasets that are labor-intensive and hard to scale, slowing progress against these attacks. 3. The authors propose an automated pipeline to generate large-scale, psychologically-grounded multi-turn jailbreak datasets by converting FITD techniques into reproducible templates, resulting in 1,500 benchmark scenarios focusing on illegal and offensive content. 4. They evaluate seven models from three major LLM families under conditions with and without conversational history to assess their vulnerability. 5. Results show that GPT-family models are significantly more vulnerable when conversational history is present, with attack success rates increasing by up to 32 percentage points. Meanwhile, Google's Gemini 2.5 Flash model shows near immunity to these attacks, and Anthropic’s Claude 3 Haiku shows strong but not perfect resistance. 6. The findings reveal a major difference in how safety architectures handle narrative context and emphasize the need for defenses that can resist manipulation through multi-turn conversational techniques.
arXiv:2511.19517v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Multi-turn conversational attacks, which leverage psychological principles like Foot-in-the-Door (FITD), where a small initial request paves the way for a more significant one, to bypass safety alignments, pose a persistent threat to Large Language Models (LLMs). Progress in defending against these attacks is hindered by a reliance on manual, hard-to-scale dataset creation. This paper introduces a novel, automated pipeline for generating large-scale, psychologically-grounded multi-turn jailbreak datasets. We systematically operationalize FITD techniques into reproducible templates, creating a benchmark of 1,500 scenarios across illegal activities and offensive content. We evaluate seven models from three major LLM families under both multi-turn (with history) and single-turn (without history) conditions. Our results reveal stark differences in contextual robustness: models in the GPT family demonstrate a significant vulnerability to conversational history, with Attack Success Rates (ASR) increasing by as much as 32 percentage points. In contrast, Google's Gemini 2.5 Flash exhibits exceptional resilience, proving nearly immune to these attacks, while Anthropic's Claude 3 Haiku shows strong but imperfect resistance. These findings highlight a critical divergence in how current safety architectures handle conversational context and underscore the need for defenses that can resist narrative-based manipulation.

item.title: Shortcut Invariance: Targeted Jacobian Regularization in Disentangled Latent Space
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: deep neural networks, shortcut learning, out-of-distribution generalization, disentangled latent space, Jacobian regularization

Summary:

1. Deep neural networks often learn shortcuts—spurious, easily learned correlations in training data—that lead to poor out-of-distribution (OOD) generalization and severe failures when encountering new data.

2. Traditional approaches focus on learning robust representations by explicitly separating latent features into core (semantic) and spurious parts, but these methods tend to be complex, brittle, and hard to scale.

3. This work proposes a fundamentally different strategy: learning a robust classifier function rather than a robust representation.

4. The method operates within a disentangled latent space, which separates core features and spurious shortcuts into distinct dimensions, thus enabling reliable identification of shortcut features by detecting their strong correlation with the label.

5. To reduce reliance on shortcuts, the classifier training injects targeted, anisotropic noise into the identified spurious latent features, which acts as a form of Jacobian regularization that desensitizes the classifier from shortcut signals.

6. This approach compels the classifier to depend on more complex, meaningful core semantic features, resulting in state-of-the-art OOD performance on established shortcut learning benchmarks.

7. The analysis interprets the noise injection as regularization on the classifier’s Jacobian, which ensures invariance to shortcut features and enhances robustness.

Overall, the paper introduces a simple yet effective training method to mitigate shortcut learning by targeting classifier invariance in a disentangled feature space, achieving superior OOD generalization.
arXiv:2511.19525v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Deep neural networks are prone to learning shortcuts, spurious and easily learned correlations in training data that cause severe failures in out-of-distribution (OOD) generalization. A dominant line of work seeks robustness by learning a robust representation, often explicitly partitioning the latent space into core and spurious components; this approach can be complex, brittle, and difficult to scale. We take a different approach, instead of a robust representation, we learn a robust function. We present a simple and effective training method that renders the classifier functionally invariant to shortcut signals. Our method operates within a disentangled latent space, which is essential as it isolates spurious and core features into distinct dimensions. This separation enables the identification of candidate shortcut features by their strong correlation with the label, used as a proxy for semantic simplicity. The classifier is then desensitized to these features by injecting targeted, anisotropic latent noise during training. We analyze this as targeted Jacobian regularization, which forces the classifier to ignore spurious features and rely on more complex, core semantic signals. The result is state-of-the-art OOD performance on established shortcut learning benchmarks.

item.title: Learning to Solve Weighted Maximum Satisfiability with a Co-Training Architecture
item.content:encoded:
SplitGNN, MaxSAT, graph neural network, edge-splitting factor graph, GPU-acceleration

Summary: The paper introduces SplitGNN, a novel graph neural network (GNN)-based approach designed to solve the weighted maximum satisfiability (MaxSAT) problem efficiently. SplitGNN features a co-training architecture combining a supervised message passing mechanism with an unsupervised solution boosting layer, enabling improved learning and solution quality. A key innovation is the edge-splitting factor graph, a new graph representation based on spanning tree generation and edge classification that provides richer structural information to the model. To tackle challenging weighted MaxSAT instances, the method includes a GPU-accelerated layer that performs efficient score calculation and relaxation-based optimization, boosting computational speed and solution accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that SplitGNN converges three times faster and achieves better prediction accuracy compared to existing GNN-based architectures. Remarkably, it outperforms state-of-the-art heuristic MaxSAT solvers on significantly larger and more complex weighted MaxSAT benchmarks. Additionally, SplitGNN shows strong generalization capabilities across diverse structural instances, highlighting its robustness and potential for broad applicability in combinatorial optimization tasks involving MaxSAT problems.
arXiv:2511.19544v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Wepropose SplitGNN, a graph neural network (GNN)-based approach that learns to solve weighted maximum satisfiabil ity (MaxSAT) problem. SplitGNN incorporates a co-training architecture consisting of supervised message passing mech anism and unsupervised solution boosting layer. A new graph representation called edge-splitting factor graph is proposed to provide more structural information for learning, which is based on spanning tree generation and edge classification. To improve the solutions on challenging and weighted instances, we implement a GPU-accelerated layer applying efficient score calculation and relaxation-based optimization. Exper iments show that SplitGNN achieves 3* faster convergence and better predictions compared with other GNN-based ar chitectures. More notably, SplitGNN successfully finds solu tions that outperform modern heuristic MaxSAT solvers on much larger and harder weighted MaxSAT benchmarks, and demonstrates exceptional generalization abilities on diverse structural instances.

item.title: When Should Neural Data Inform Welfare? A Critical Framework for Policy Uses of Neuroeconomics
item.content:encoded:
neuroeconomics, welfare analysis, reinforcement learning, neural data, policy regulation

Summary:

1. The paper explores the potential and limitations of using neural data to inform welfare judgments in policy-making rather than merely describing behavior.

2. It develops a theoretical framework linking neural signals, computational decision models (specifically actor-critic reinforcement learning), and normative welfare criteria to clarify when neural evidence can meaningfully support welfare claims.

3. The framework formalizes the inference from neural activity to latent variables such as values and prediction errors, and then to welfare assessments.

4. The author argues that neural data can only constrain welfare judgments if three conditions are met: a well-validated neural-to-computational mapping, decision models that distinguish true interests from context-dependent errors, and explicitly stated and justified welfare criteria.

5. Applying this approach to domains including addiction, neuromarketing, and environmental policy, the paper proposes a Neuroeconomic Welfare Inference Checklist intended for regulators and NeuroAI designers.

6. The analysis treats both brains and artificial agents as value-learning systems and emphasizes that internal reward signals are computational constructs that cannot serve as welfare measures absent an explicit normative model.
arXiv:2511.19548v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Neuroeconomics promises to ground welfare analysis in neural and computational evidence about how people value outcomes, learn from experience and exercise self-control. At the same time, policy and commercial actors increasingly invoke neural data to justify paternalistic regulation, "brain-based" interventions and new welfare measures. This paper asks under what conditions neural data can legitimately inform welfare judgements for policy rather than merely describing behaviour. I develop a non-empirical, model-based framework that links three levels: neural signals, computational decision models and normative welfare criteria. Within an actor-critic reinforcement-learning model, I formalise the inference path from neural activity to latent values and prediction errors and then to welfare claims. I show that neural evidence constrains welfare judgements only when the neural-computational mapping is well validated, the decision model identifies "true" interests versus context-dependent mistakes, and the welfare criterion is explicitly specified and defended. Applying the framework to addiction, neuromarketing and environmental policy, I derive a Neuroeconomic Welfare Inference Checklist for regulators and for designers of NeuroAI systems. The analysis treats brains and artificial agents as value-learning systems while showing that internal reward signals, whether biological or artificial, are computational quantities and cannot be treated as welfare measures without an explicit normative model.

item.title: Online Sparse Feature Selection in Data Streams via Differential Evolution
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Online Streaming Feature Selection, Missing Data Imputation, Differential Evolution, Latent Factor Analysis, Sparse Feature Selection

Summary: This paper addresses the challenges in processing high-dimensional streaming data, particularly focusing on online streaming feature selection (OSFS) techniques. A major problem in practical scenarios is data incompleteness caused by equipment failures and technical constraints. To overcome this, existing Online Sparse Streaming Feature Selection (OS2FS) methods use latent factor analysis-based missing data imputation but still suffer from inefficient feature evaluation, which leads to degraded performance. The authors propose a novel method named Online Differential Evolution for Sparse Feature Selection (ODESFS) designed for data streams. ODESFS introduces two critical improvements: firstly, it employs a latent factor analysis model for more effective missing value imputation, ensuring better handling of incomplete data; secondly, it uses differential evolution to evaluate feature importance, which enhances the accuracy and selection of optimal feature subsets. The effectiveness of ODESFS is validated through comprehensive experiments on six real-world datasets, demonstrating its superiority over state-of-the-art OSFS and OS2FS methods. The results show that ODESFS consistently selects better feature subsets and achieves higher classification accuracy, proving its potential for practical streaming data applications with incomplete and high-dimensional data.
arXiv:2511.19555v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The processing of high-dimensional streaming data commonly utilizes online streaming feature selection (OSFS) techniques. However, practical implementations often face challenges with data incompleteness due to equipment failures and technical constraints. Online Sparse Streaming Feature Selection (OS2FS) tackles this issue through latent factor analysis-based missing data imputation. Despite this advancement, existing OS2FS approaches exhibit substantial limitations in feature evaluation, resulting in performance deterioration. To address these shortcomings, this paper introduces a novel Online Differential Evolution for Sparse Feature Selection (ODESFS) in data streams, incorporating two key innovations: (1) missing value imputation using a latent factor analysis model, and (2) feature importance evaluation through differential evolution. Comprehensive experiments conducted on six real-world datasets demonstrate that ODESFS consistently outperforms state-of-the-art OSFS and OS2FS methods by selecting optimal feature subsets and achieving superior accuracy.

item.title: Merging without Forgetting: Continual Fusion of Task-Specific Models via Optimal Transport
item.content:encoded:
Optimal Transport, Model Merging, Multi-task Learning, Masked Fusion, Continual Fusion

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of merging models fine-tuned on different tasks into a single unified multi-task model. Existing methods mostly rely on parameter interpolation in weight space, which leads to significant distribution shifts in feature space and loss of task-specific knowledge. To overcome this, the authors propose OTMF (Optimal Transport-based Masked Fusion), a novel framework grounded in optimal transport theory. Instead of interpolating weights or features directly, OTMF aligns the semantic geometry of task-specific models by discovering common masks applied to task vectors through optimal transport plans. These masks selectively extract transferable and task-agnostic components while maintaining the unique structural properties of each individual task. The framework also supports a continual fusion paradigm, enabling incremental integration of new tasks without revisiting previous models, thus ensuring scalability and a bounded memory footprint. Extensive experiments conducted on various vision and language benchmarks demonstrate that OTMF achieves state-of-the-art results in terms of accuracy and efficiency. Overall, the study highlights both the practical applications and theoretical contributions of adopting optimal transport and masked fusion for efficient, scalable, and effective multi-task model merging.
arXiv:2511.19561v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Merging models fine-tuned for different tasks into a single unified model has become an increasingly important direction for building versatile, efficient multi-task systems. Existing approaches predominantly rely on parameter interpolation in weight space, which we show introduces significant distribution shift in the feature space and undermines task-specific knowledge. In this paper, we propose OTMF (Optimal Transport-based Masked Fusion), a novel model merging framework rooted in optimal transport theory to address the distribution shift that arises from naive parameter interpolation. Instead of directly aggregating features or weights, OTMF aligns the semantic geometry of task-specific models by discovering common masks applied to task vectors through optimal transport plans. These masks selectively extract transferable and task-agnostic components while preserving the unique structural identities of each task. To ensure scalability in real-world settings, OTMF further supports a continual fusion paradigm that incrementally integrates each new task vector without revisiting previous ones, maintaining a bounded memory footprint and enabling efficient fusion across a growing number of tasks. We conduct comprehensive experiments on multiple vision and language benchmarks, and results show that OTMF achieves state-of-the-art performance in terms of both accuracy and efficiency. These findings highlight the practical and theoretical value of our approach to model merging.

item.title: ModHiFi: Identifying High Fidelity predictive components for Model Modification
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: model modification, Subset Fidelity, pruning, unlearning, Lipschitz continuity

Summary: This work addresses the challenge of modifying open weight models without access to training data, loss functions, or gradients—a common limitation in many deployed models. The authors theoretically prove that for Lipschitz-continuous networks such as CNNs and well-trained Transformers, the global reconstruction error can be bounded linearly by local reconstruction errors of component subsets. This insight leads to the proposal of a new metric called Subset Fidelity, which assesses the global importance of model components via their local reconstructive behavior. In scenarios where features are uncorrelated, selecting components based on Subset Fidelity is theoretically optimal. Building on this, the authors design ModHiFi, an algorithm that modifies models using only distributional access, such as synthetic inputs, requiring no ground-truth labels or gradients. Two variants are developed: ModHiFi-P for structured pruning, which achieves an 11% speedup over current state-of-the-art methods on ImageNet while maintaining competitive performance on language models; and ModHiFi-U for classwise unlearning, which achieves complete unlearning on CIFAR-10 without fine-tuning and demonstrates strong results on Swin Transformers. This work opens new avenues for efficient model modification under limited information scenarios.
arXiv:2511.19566v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Open weight models, which are ubiquitous, rarely provide access to their training data or loss function. This makes modifying such models for tasks such as pruning or unlearning constrained by this unavailability an active area of research. Existing techniques typically require gradients or ground-truth labels, rendering them infeasible in settings with limited computational resources. In this work, we investigate the fundamental question of identifying components that are critical to the model's predictive performance, without access to either gradients or the loss function, and with only distributional access such as synthetic data. We theoretically demonstrate that the global reconstruction error is linearly bounded by local reconstruction errors for Lipschitz-continuous networks such as CNNs and well-trained Transformers (which, contrary to existing literature, we find exhibit Lipschitz continuity). This motivates using the locally reconstructive behavior of component subsets to quantify their global importance, via a metric that we term Subset Fidelity. In the uncorrelated features setting, selecting individual components via their Subset Fidelity scores is optimal, which we use to propose ModHiFi, an algorithm for model modification that requires no training data or loss function access. ModHiFi-P, for structured pruning, achieves an 11% speedup over the current state of the art on ImageNet models and competitive performance on language models. ModHiFi-U, for classwise unlearning, achieves complete unlearning on CIFAR-10 without fine-tuning and demonstrates competitive performance on Swin Transformers.

item.title: An Invariant Latent Space Perspective on Language Model Inversion
item.content:encoded:
